24 Resolutions . A resolution is also a binding measure available to members and Ministers to discuss any matter of the common people in the House .
Unlike motions in general सदनों Draft of resolutions have been provided in the Rules of Procedure of both Houses.
Effect of Motions or Resolutions adopted by the House By voting on a motion or a resolution the House declares its opinion on the subject matter and becomes an order of the House .
As far as their impact is concerned resolutions passed by the Parliament fall in the following categories :
Resolutions expressing merely an opinion are not binding on the government .
The practice is that the decisions expressed in these resolutions are wholly dependent on the discretion of the government .
Resolutions adopted by the House in matters of its own proceedings are binding and have the force of law .
Their validity cannot be challenged in courts .
Resolutions having a statutory effect - if adopted are binding on the government and have the power of law .
In such a situation would the resolution be deemed to be a censure against the government ?
However after leave by the House if the member wants to withdraw his motion he can do so only with the permission of the House .
Notice of no - confidence motion can also be withdrawn by all the members who have signed the notice of the motion and it should be carried before the item is taken up in the House .
In that case the item in the House is not mentioned or brought before the House .
Rajya Sabha has no power to consider a no - confidence motion as the government under the Constitution is collectively responsible to the elected Lok Sabha only .
A censure motion is distinct from a no - confidence motion .
The motion of no - confidence does not refer to the reasons on which it is based but the censure motion requires a reference to such reasons or allegations and it is moved for the specific purpose of सरकार the government for certain policies and actions .
है motion is moved against the Council of Ministers or against any one minister or against some ministers or against some of them or against any of their policies in which the failure of any minister or ministers is खेद by the House .
The motion should be specific and self - explanatory so as to record the reasons for the censure precisely and briefly .
The Speaker ' s decision whether the motion is in order or not for any reason is final .
No leave of the House is required to move a censure motion .

The Constitution provides that no tax shall be levied or collected except by the authority of Parliament and that the President shall in respect of each financial year cause an annual financial statement before both the Houses .

For the sake of convenience Financial Bills may be placed in the following two categories:
Category A Bill which gives धन to any of the matters referred to in the Money Act in Art. 110 but simply not provided for the same cases - - in which there is a mere taxation .
Category b Such Bills containing provisions involving expenditure from the Consolidated Fund .
Accordingly all Financial Bills are not Money Bills .

Besides there is a slight procedural difference between the passage of Money Bills and Financial Bills by both the Houses .

Committee on Private Members' Bills and Resolutions : This Committee of Lok Sabha consists of 15 members with the Deputy Speaker as its Chairman .

The सदस्यो Committee of the members from the sittings of the House provides in the Constitution that if any member of either House has been absent from all the Houses for a period of 60 days from all the sittings of the House .
In order to facilitate the Lok Sabha constituted a Committee of 15 members to consider requests from members seeking leave of absence from the House .
In the Rajya Sabha such matters are considered by the House itself .
The functions of the Committee are : ( i ) to consider all cases received from members for leave of absence from the sittings of the House ; and ( two ) to investigate every case in which a member has been released from the sittings of the House .
The Committee also performs such other functions in connection with the attendance of members of the House as may be assigned to it by the Speaker from time to time .
Rules Committee : Each House has a Rules Committee .
In Lok Sabha the Rules Committee consists of 15 members including the Speaker who is the ex - officio Chairman of the Committee .
In the Rajya Sabha the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman are 16 members of the Committee .
Suggestions for amendments or additions to the Rules can be made by any member of the House minister or the Committee itself .
The Committee thus acts as an Ombudsman or Public Grievances Committee .
The Committee of सदन : Each House of Parliament has individually and collectively some privileges from the House to which they are subject to certain powers and duties without which the House and its members cannot effectively discharge their functions .
When a question of breach of privilege arises even though the House is competent to deal with it it is generally referred to the Committee of Privileges existing in either House for examination investigation and reporting .
The Committee of Privileges is constituted usually by the Presiding Officers of the respective Houses.
It has 15 members in Lok Sabha and 10 members in Rajya Sabha .
The functions of the Committee are of semi - judicial nature and it contains wide powers .
Though its findings are subject to the ultimate decision of the House it enjoys the confidence of the House and its recommendations are seldom rejected .
The Committee plays an important role in safeguarding the powers and prestige of Parliament and Parliament .

The Committee on Papers Laid on the Table : At every session the government lays before the Parliament its statements statements statements statements statements reports and papers either in pursuance of constitutional provisions or in reply to questions or suo के to inform members of Parliament on various matters .
Some of these reports / papers may be referred to various parliamentary committees including the Committee on Subordinate Legislation but most of them remain to be examined in detail by the Committee on Papers Laid on the Table which is constituted by either House of Parliament .
The Committee has 15 members in Lok Sabha and 10 members in Rajya Sabha .
The Committee examines all the papers placed on the Table of the House and reports in pursuance of such delay in pursuance of the provisions of the Constitution under which it is placed on the Table of the House or under the Act विनियम Rules or Regulations .

The idea of a separate or independent executive from the Government of India for the Indian Legislature came into force in January 1932 when a separate office was set up for the Presiding Officers of Legislative Bodies in India held by भाई Bhai Patel .
On the 22nd September 1928 the famous leader Motilal Nehru moved a resolution in the then Central Legislative Assembly supported by another illustrious leader Lala Lajpat Rai and the intention of the resolution was to constitute a separate Assembly Department .
In fact the same resolution became the source of the creation and authority of the Assembly Department .
As a result a separate Department called the Legislative Assembly Department was set up on January 10 1929 in the portfolio of the Lieutenant - Governor - General with the President of the Legislative Assembly as its de facto head .
The name of the Department continued to remain the same until 26 January 1950 when the Constitution of India came into force and the creation of the Provisional Parliament it was changed to Parliament Secretariat .
Their names were changed to लोक Sabha . and Rajya Sabha . respectively in 1954 .

His President is the President ; he contains all the executive powers and is used in his name .
He is also the highest commander of the armed forces .
But unlike the American President our President is only a nominal or constitutional head of the Executive .
On the contrary the U. S. President ' s Presidential Rule consists of separation of powers and the President is the chief executive for a fixed term and cannot be dismissed more often .
In the U. S. system the President chooses his minister from among the common citizens and the ministers are not members of a legislature while in the parliamentary system ministers go from Parliament and remain part of it and responsible to the Lok Sabha .
It may be said that the parliamentary system emphasizes the concepts of executive responsibility while the Presidential system clearly gives more importance to the stability of the Executive .
But it would be wrong to say that we have completely adopted the British parliamentary system .
For instance the U. S. Constitution is a unitary while ours is largely federal .

Before the Forty - second Amendment the only mention of the term ' धार्मिक ' was in Article 25 ( 2 ) of the Constitution where the state was empowered to regulate or restrict any secular activity associated with religious practices .
It is clear that the term धार्मिक was used here in the sense of the worldly or in the sense of cases other than pure religious .
The Forty - second Constitutional Amendment Act which added the word secular did not attempt to define it .
But it was felt that the addition was only to approve and explain the fact which was believed to have been already present as a basic feature of the Constitution .
The founding fathers sought to provide for the vast adult population of the country full representation by giving the fullest powers without any literacy division of income tax or males .
There is no hereditary ruler and the head of the state is elected by the people for a certain period .
He is usually called the President of the Republic .
Democratic republic therefore broadly means a State consisting of the elected President and the government of the people .
All citizens are equal in the eyes of law and there is no privileged class and all public offices are open to every citizen without any distinction based on either caste creed or community .
The membership of the Commonwealth even though India decided to remain a member of the Commonwealth - LRB - Commonwealth - RRB - it made no sign of its position as a sovereign nation or as a Republic .
In fact the Commonwealth was transformed .
In this positive connotation liberty would mean freedom of the individual to act according to his will .
Liberty of thought , faith and worship as elaborated in the fundamental rights part of the Constitution has to be so regulated as not to endanger the security of the State public interest etc .
Leaders of the French Revolution believed that all men were equal in the eyes of law .
Whether it protected or punished it must do so without any regard to distinction of birth etc.
Moreover all citizens of England are equally eligible for all public offices honours and positions strictly according to their capacities virtues and talents .
In the case of पुरुष equality does not mean that all men ( and women ) are equal in all circumstances .
There must be physical mental and economic differences between them .
Finally the reorganization of States under the Constitution ( Seventh Amendment ) Act 1956 abolished the distinction between Part A and Part B states .

Where India was the ancient name and represented the first expression of the consciousness of the unity and integrity of the country India was the modern name which had made the country known all over the world .
As a member of the United Nations also its name was India and all international agreements were entered in that name .
Both the names therefore had strong followers .
Finally the name 'India that is India ' was adopted as a happy compromise .
India is a " Union ; it was intended to emphasise the fact that it was not the result of a bargaining or an agreement between the constituent units but a clear declaration of its power and authority to India .
No State could therefore secede from the Union nor could it suo की vary its territory as laid down in the First Schedule to the Constitution .
Article 2 provides that Parliament by law may by law admit or establish new States in the Union of India on such terms and conditions as it deems fit .
The latest addition to the Union was the State of Sikkim by the 35th and संविधान Constitutional Amendments in 1974 and 1975 .
This was done at the request of the Sikkim Assembly and with the approval of the people of Sikkim through a plebiscite .
Under article 3 Parliament has power to form a new State by separating a part of the territory of a State or by uniting two or more States or parts of States or by uniting any territory with a part of any State .
It can increase or decrease the area of a State and can also alter the boundaries or even the name of a State .
Thus there is no guarantee of the territorial integrity or continued existence of a State .
But at the same time it has been held that the Parliament ' s power to diminish the area of any State does not include the power to devote the Indian territory to a foreign State .
- LRB - ii - RRB - बस्तियों of trade and commerce AIR 1950 SC विनियम (
Therefore India is the indestructible Union of राज्यों states .
It represents the individual having full political membership of the State : his permanent allegiance to the state and the acceptance by the state of his integration into the political system .
Citizenship provides certain obligations powers immunities and कर्तव्य .
All public offices are open to the citizen .
The right to vote and certain fundamental rights are available only to citizens and citizens have obligations like paying taxes defending the nation and so on .
Citizenship may also be viewed as the legal relationship between the individual and the state under which the individual pledges his loyalty to the State and the State offers its protection to the individual .
This relationship is regulated by national law and recognized by international law .
On 26 November 1949 the Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution and at once brought into force articles 5 to 9 relating to citizenship .
By that time those of us who lived in British India were under the Crown and thus British subjects .
The partition of India and massive migrations created stupendous problems for citizenship determination .
Citizenship provisions in the Constitution - articles 5 to 11 - gave the Constitution Drafting Committee the maximum headache and took a large number of drafts and more than two years to be finalized.
Still in the Constitution only the law was laid down in regard to who would be citizens of India at the time of the commencement of the Constitution .
It did not provide for the mode of acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Article 11 said that Parliament could regulate the right of citizenship by law .
Under article 5 - 8 " All Indians were given citizenship for a particular period which existed in India for the first time but since the inception of the Constitution were born in पाकिस्तान and in fact more than 1948 .
Thus Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution included provisions for citizenship by domicile ( e ) on grounds of domicile ( ii ) migrants from Pakistan and for persons there ; and ( व्यक्तियों ) Indians residing abroad .
domicile is a vital criterion for citizenship of a country .
Raza v. State of Bombay AIR 1966 SC 1966 ) .
Article 5 provides that if a person resident in the territory of India lives on the commencement of the Constitution ( i . e . ii ) first in the territory of India ( i . e . i . e . ii . ( ii )
Domicile by birth or residence as a person can be changed .
In fact अधिवास citizenship is denoted by domicile and not vice - versa.
domicile is different from citizenship because it is mainly connected with the territory and not membership of the community which is at the root of the principle of citizenship ( Abdul Rahman v. State of Bombay AIR 1964 बंबई .
The single citizenship gives and its relationship is domicile in the territory of the whole of India and not in any part of it .
There is no separate citizenship of the state in India as in the United States .
His domicile is only one domicile namely domicile in the territory of India .
( Pradeep Jain v. Union of India AIR 1984 SC प्रदीप प्रदीप )
A person migrating from Pakistan Article 6 provides for citizenship rights of migrants from Pakistan before the commencement of the Constitution .
This kind of migrants have two types of distinctions : i. e. those migrating to India before July 19 1948 when the permit system for migration was introduced in India before the प्रवास and those who came after that date .
A man who had migrated to India before July 19 1948 and settled in India will be deemed to be a citizen of India at the beginning of the Constitution provided as one of his parents or a नागरिक or a rule in India .
Thus नागरिकता - all Indians residing abroad have been taken into account the future citizenship requirements .
Voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country Article 9 provides that if a person has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of a foreign State he shall forfeit the right of citizenship of India .
This provision was applicable to cases arising before the commencement of the Constitution but in matters arising after the commencement of the Constitution the cases arising after the commencement of the Constitution the procedure shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Citizenship Act 1955 .
The Supreme Court has held that it is the business of the Government of India to determine whether a person has been deprived of citizenship of India by acquisition of citizenship of another country and after that a state government can enter into a foreign manner .

Article 10 lays down that every person who is a citizen of India under any of the provisions made in Articles 5 to 10 is deemed to be citizen of India subject to the citizenship of India subject to the provisions of such laws .
In other words it means that a citizen ' s right to citizenship cannot be छीना in any other manner apart from parliamentary legislation .
- LRB - Ibrahim Wazir v. State of Bombay AIR 1954 SC 229 ) .
Article 5 and the term कारावास used in 10 are interpreted to cover all persons who may be in jail under trial or who may be undergoing imprisonment .

Parliament ' s power to regulate the right of Citizenship by law and the Citizenship Act 1955 Article 11 endows Parliament with unfettered powers for enacting legislation relating to the acquisition and termination of the citizenship of India and all matters connected therewith.
Accordingly the Parliament passed the Citizenship Act है 1955 providing for acquisition and termination of citizenship .
Thus all matters relating to the citizenship rights after the commencement of the Constitution are to be dealt with in accordance with its provisions .
This Act was amended in 1986 to tackle the situation created by the large - scale unlawful immigration into India of people from Bangladesh श्रीलंका Sri Lanka and some African countries .
This amendment made the acquisition of Indian citizenship more difficult .

The Government of India Act . 1919 : By the 1919 सुधान Act and rules made under it many important changes were introduced in the Indian constitutional system .

The Government of India Act 1935 aims at providing for federal structure .
It provided that in the discharge of the functions of the Governor - General he would not be required to perform his duties " except in the case of a situation where he would be required to perform his functions " or according to his personal views " .
The Federal Legislature . individual or collective responsibility of the ministers was not mentioned in the Act though each minister was expected to be a member of either House of the Legislature .
He could preside over meetings of the Council of Ministers with his discretion.
The Act provided that the Federal Legislature consisted of ( emperor ) represented by the Governor - General and two Chambers to be known respectively as the Council of State ( Upper House ) and the House of Assembly ( Lower House of Assembly ) .
The Council of State would be a permanent body not subject to dissolution but one - third of its members retire every third year .
Every Federal Assembly would have served for five years unless it was भंग by the Governor - General in his discretion.
Each House was to elect its Chairman and Deputy Chairman and shall while subject to the provisions of the सदन Act be empowered to regulate its own procedure and action .
The Governor - General in his discretion has the power to invite and prorogue the Legislature and to dissolve the Lower House .
A Bill shall not become law unless agreed to by the two Houses and assented to by the Governor - General or a Bill reserved for the purpose of His Majesty ' s desire ?
Even an Act assented to by the Governor - General could be disallowed by His Majesty .
The Governor - General could remit a Bill to the Houses for reconsideration .
In the case of disagreement between the Houses the Governor - General could summon a joint sitting in which decisions could be arrived at by a majority the two Houses were practically equal powers ; the latter being distinguishable from the सदनों financial sphere .
Money Bills could be introduced only in the Lower House but the Upper House had the power to amend or reject them in the same way as the Lower House and the Governor - General was empowered to resolve the differences by summoning a joint sitting .

The people need an organisation or a medium by which they can express and possess their sovereign .
Under the scheme of our Constitution and its provision of universal adult franchise people exercise their sovereign power while casting their votes to elect representatives to the Union Parliament .
Parliament becomes the people ' s institution par excellence through which the sovereign will of the people finds expression .
In the beginning the Indo - Greek City States or the cities of India and during the Vedic period the people themselves assembled together to decide government matters .
People thus exercised their power directly to decide matters of the state and this kind of polity could be called direct democracy .
But with the gradual increase in the size and population of political parties and ultimately with the formation of modern nation - states it became impossible for the people to assemble at a place to discuss matters of state and arrive at decisions smoothly.
All forms of direct democracy therefore soon became practically extinct all over the world except in some of Switzerland in Switzerland where they can still be decided by people on different matters .
Modern democracy has become necessary to have a representative democracy where people exercise their sovereign power through their elected representatives .
The term संसदीय means a specially democratic political order where sovereignty vests in a body of people ' s representatives called Parliament .
This is the pivot of the nation ' s political system .
The President of the Republic is directly elected by the Election Board consisting of elected members of both Houses of Parliament and elected members of the State Assemblies .
Though the President of India is a part of Parliament he does not sit in either House or participate in its discussions .

He can prorogue the two Houses of Parliament and dissolve the Lok Sabha .
Moreover whilst the two Houses of Parliament are not in session and the President is satisfied that there exist conditions which are necessary for them to be dealt with immediately by an ordinance which has been passed by Parliament and so on .
Moreover he has the power to decide after obtaining the opinion of the Election Commission whether a duly elected member is subject to the disqualifications laid down in Article 108 of the Constitution .
His decision in this matter is final .

The populations in some of the Union Territories such as Andaman and Nicobar Islands Chandigarh Dadra and Nagar Haveli Daman and Diu and Lakshadweep are too small to be represented in the Rajya Sabha .
Under the Constitution Rajya Sabha consists of not more than 250 members .

The Government of India Act . 1935 the most remarkable feature of the Government of India Act 1935 was that it envisaged an all - India federation of the Indian states willing to join the British provinces and the Union .
By the 1930 Round Table Conference India was a unitary state and whatever powers the Provinces possessed were given to them by the Centre .
The 1935 Act for the first time provided for a federal system which would include not only the Provinces of British India but also the Chief रियासतें province and the princely states .
It finally broke the unitary system under which British India had so far been administered .
The principle of the constitution of 1919 was decentralisation rather than decentralization .
Provinces were free from Central control in the area under normal conditions .
The Act separated Burma from India and created two new provinces of Orissa and Sind .
In view of the proposed scheme at the Centre eleven provinces of the गवर्नरों were transferred completely from the " supervision and control of the Central Government and the Secretary of State except for certain specific purposes .
In other words the कर Provinces were given a separate legal personality .
Moreover Parliament is empowered to abolish or create a Legislative Council in a State by a simple procedure not involving an amendment of the Constitution .
This can only be done by an Act of Parliament if the Legislative Assembly of a State passes a resolution to this effect by a special majority .
The final but important thing is that Parliament exercises some control over the states through the Governor .
As we know : The President is a constituent of the Parliament and at the same time he is also the head of the Executive of the Union .
Governors of states are appointed by them and they hold office during the pleasure of the President .
Moreover the President may make such provisions in any contingency not provided for in the Constitution for the discharge of the functions of the Governor of the State which he thinks fit .
All these facts however do not imply that there are only administrative agents in the State in India .
There is no one in your area subject to each other .
In the words of Dr Ambedkar the States are as sovereign as in the sphere assigned to them by the Constitution .
The scheme of provincial autonomy envisaged by the Act provided for a executive and a legislature in every province .
The Council of Ministers was made responsible to the Legislature and could dismiss it by passing a no - confidence motion .
The Legislature could exercise some control over the administration through questions and supplementary questions .

Secretary - General is the third important officer of the House.
He is the adviser to the Speaker to the House and to the members on all parliamentary functions and activities and in all matters relating to procedure and practice .
As a permanent officer who is the principal officer of the Table and continues to serve as a continuous link between the changing various chambers and the Speakers General Secretary - General is the custodian of parliamentary conventions and traditions and fore - सदनों of the Houses first .
The Secretary - General discharges in his own right many legislative functions administrative and executive functions and renders services and facilities to the members .
He is the highest incharge of the Watch and Ward Organisation and the security in the precincts of Parliament property .
The Parliament Library also works under it the संसद Research Reference Documentation and Information Services .
He is responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the buildings and properties of the Parliament .
As the overall head of the parliamentary Museum and Archives he is the custodian of the heritage of Parliament and the keeper of all parliamentary records .
He is the head of the legislative services and the Secretariat of the House and is responsible for its administration for maintaining discipline and for ensuring that the secretarial work of the House and its Committees is conducted efficiently and efficiently and efficiently .
He provides secretarial assistance and staff to all the Parliamentary Committees and is available to them for advice.
His role for the members and committees is that of a friend philosopher and guide .
Members of different political parties approach him for advice .
To a great extent he has to maintain the same role of impartiality and objectivity as that observed by the Speaker .
He must be fully conscious and व्यक्ति or soon व्यक्ति .
For a person holding the post of Secretary - General it is necessary that he is a genius and a master in the manifold functions of the Parliament he / she is entrusted with such a more technical and complicated nature that he is able to all grades .
Work is organised in such a manner that each unit acts a particular subject or aspect of parliamentary life and is equipped with talented employees who are technically equipped and who discharge their duties efficiently.
It is the duty of the Secretary - General to see that adequate personnel should be trained to fill the gaps occurring from time to time and that the efficiency of parliamentary work remains at a high level .
Much therefore depends upon the personality and mind of the occupant of the post of Secretary - General in giving shape and character to the secretarial सदन of the House .
His approach and perspective are always absolutely non - party and unbiased .
He is chosen from among the officers who have done commendable work in serving the Parliament by acting in various capacities in the Secretariat of the House .
The Speaker is the authority to choose and appoint him .
Once appointed he shall age a person who is now 60 years old and continue to be in his office until he attains the age of retiring .
He is not subject to criticism in the House and his actions in the House or outside are not discussed .
It is only the responsibility of the Speaker in order to safeguard the service and to give independence adequate safeguards in this respect that he performs his duties in a most humane and just fair measure .
The Lok Sabha Secretariat is completely separate and under the control of the Speaker so that the Parliament can get independent advice and its directions can be executed well without any outside interference or inner pressure .

In such a situation it is not necessary to have the permission of the House to pass a Bill .
In other words the Bill does not go through stage of introduction .
( ii ) Second Reading of the Bill is the most detailed and important stage in which it is examined in detail and minute details .
The second reading or the consideration stage consists of two steps which may be called the first stage and the second stage .
First stage there is a general discussion on the whole Bill ; the विधेयक i . e . i . e . the concepts underlying the Bill and its details .
At this stage the House may either refer the Bill to the Select Committee of the House or the Joint Committee of the two Houses or circulated to it for eliciting opinion thereon.
A Bill may be referred to a Select Committee or a Joint Committee .
The members of the Select Committee are drawn from among the members of the House to which the Bill has been introduced .
In the case of the Joint Committee members of both the Houses are represented ; in such a case the ratio between members of the Rajya Sabha and Rajya Sabha is 2 : 1 .
The Chairman of the Joint Committee is appointed by the Presiding Officer of the House in which the Bill has been introduced .
The Bill thereafter passes through the Committee stage and the Bill is presented as a विधेयक report to the House .

The failure of the Simon Commission and the Round Table Conference which led to the establishment of the . Government of India Act 1935 which inspired the demands of the Constituent Assembly for the people of India .
The Congress adopted a resolution at its Lucknow Session in April 1936 .
The demand was firmly reiterated at the All India National Conference of Congress Legislators held in Delhi in March 1937 .
In August - October 1937 the same resolution was passed by the Central Legislative Assembly and the Provincial Assemblies of each of the Provinces .
After the Great War in 1939 the demand for a Constituent Assembly was repeated in a long statement issued by the Congress Working Committee on 14 September 1939 .
They declared that the only way to a just solution to communal and other problems was also the Constituent Assembly .
In the August 1940 the British Government accepted the demand for the Constituent Assembly for the first time officially though with the acceptance indirect and important conditions .
According to these proposals the task of building a new Constitution was now to be entirely Indian and the British Government made a clear undertaking to accept the constitution framed by the proposed constitution - making body .
After the failure of the Cripps Mission no steps were taken to resolve the Indian constitutional problem until the War in Europe came to an end in May 1945 .
As in case of Joint Committees the Council of Public Accounts is drawn from the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha members of the Committee on Public Undertakings and Committee on Welfare of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and Members of Government assurances from both the Houses .

The Parliamentary Committee holds office for a period not exceeding one year or for a period specified by the Speaker or until a new Committee is मनोनीत
The Business Advisory Committee . Committee . on Petitions Committee on Privileges and the Rules Committee continue in office till re - constituted whereas other Standing Committees hold office for a period not exceeding one year .

The Committee ' s procedure is held in the Parliament House or Parliament House Annexe but in special cases their meetings can be held out with the permission of the Speaker / Chairman as the case may be .
The Committee has the power to take oral or written evidence .
The Committee may call upon the person for evidence on the दस्तावेज document and record but if a question arises that any person or evidence or a document is referred to or not to the Speaker for the purposes of the Committee .

A sub - committee report is presented to the main committee .
There is no public hearing .
The proceedings in Committees are largely conducted in the same way as in the House but in the Committees there are more informal activities and on non - party basis .
A member may speak more than once on a question under consideration in the Committee .
All questions are decided by a majority of members present and voting .
In case of an equal division of votes on a matter the Chairman has a second or casting vote .
Thereafter the Committee drafts a report thereafter on the basis of the कार्यवाही of the sittings of the Committee containing the substance of deliberations of the Committee together with the recommendations.
They can make internal rules of the process themselves which require approval by the Speaker .
These Committees ordinarily do not go into questions of policy as policy formulation is a matter of complete involvement of Parliament and a Committee is not supposed to determine a policy already approved by Parliament .
In order to avoid possible interference in day - to - day administration the Committees examine only those acts which have already been done or not done which otherwise परंतु

The founding fathers were committed to adherence to the practice of universal adult suffrage with every adult Indian without any distinction at once having equal rights to no discrimination .
The most fundamental demand among the leaders of our national struggle for freedom was that people had some basic human rights such as freedom equality and so on .
The problems of minorities accentuated the need for a formal declaration of certain fundamental rights in the text of the Constitution itself that could be made applicable to some वाद or courts .

A hostile habitat
The deep sea marked by temperature and non - sunlight and at great pressure is an alien habitation for us .
We can only expect a few species to live there .
When Gordon and his colleagues collected samples from the ocean floor they were amazed by the diversity of animal species there - a diversity that rivals anything found on earth and in shallow water .
How do so many species survive in such an adverse environment ?

Citizenship In keeping with its objective of building an integrated Indian fraternity and a united nation the founding fathers made provisions for a single citizenship without a federal structure .
Unlike the United States there is no separate citizenship for the Union and the States and all citizens across the country have been given equal rights to all citizens without any discrimination - only Kashmir tribal areas etc where some special protection has been granted .
Fundamental Duties The 42nd Amendment to the Constitution inter alia added a new Part to the Constitution under the title कर्तव्य ' Fundamental Duties .
In fact no right can be viable without corresponding duty and the rights of citizens without respect for the political obligations of the citizens on the State .
The Constitution of India provides an independent judiciary .
The High Courts and the Supreme Court form a single integrated judicial structure with jurisdiction over all laws Union Territories - LRB - State - RRB - civil criminal or constitutional laws .
Unlike the United States non - federal and State court systems are not there in our country .
He विवादों disputes and functions not only as the custodian of personal rights and freedoms but can be expected to do timely interpretation of the Constitution and to lay down the validity of any legislation in the context of the Constitution .

Conclusion The Constitution of India is one of the most comprehensive documents .
It is unique in many ways .
It cannot be fitted into a certain mould structure or model .
It is a blend of the rigid and the flexible federal and unitary system and presidential and parliamentary forms .
It attempts to maintain a balance between the fundamental rights of individuals on the one hand and the social economic interests of the people and the security of the state .
Moreover it presents a via media between the principles of parliamentary sovereignty and judicial supremacy.
While many Constitutions of nations framed after the Second World War have been divided and lost ; our Constitution has successfully faced many crises and survived.
This is proof of his resilience dynamism and growth potential .

The Charter Act 1853 was the final Charter Act by which important changes were made in the Governor - General ' s Council .
The Council ' s fourth or legislative member was given equal status to other members by granting the right to appear and vote at executive meetings .
At the same time the Council was enlarged for legislative purposes by the addition of six special members who were designated as the legislative पार्षद .
Thus in addition to the Governor - General and the Commander - in - Chief the Council constituted under the Act of 1853 was twelve members .

The Indian Council of 1861 : The object of the Act was to make better arrangements for the constitution of the Council of the Governor - General and for the local government in many provinces .

Though the term ' was not deliberately used the practice of non - official members of the Provincial Council recommended and sent their nominees to the Central Council indicated how to accept the principle of indirect election.

In case of Emergency the Governor - General ' s power to promulgate ordinances for the peace and good governance of British India .

If the Executive has almost unlimited power to formulate legislative and financial proposals and direct them to the Parliament and to carry out policies which are adopted by Parliament without the resistance of government it is proposed to go ahead with the Parliament to obtain information .
The Executive and the administration are responsible to the Parliament .
The function of Parliament is to exercise political and financial control over the Executive and to ensure parliamentary surveillance of administration .
Parliament has the power to make laws regulating the constitution organisation jurisdiction and powers of courts .
The Constitution envisaged that the number of judges other than the Chief Justice would not exceed seven .
Parliament was however empowered to determine by law a large number of judges .
Under this provision Parliament ( iii ) passed the Supreme Court ( न्यायाधीशों ) Act in which the number of other judges was enlarged to ten and subsequently by several amendments to the Act .
Thus at present the number of judges of the Supreme Court including the Chief Justice is 26 .
Each state has a High Court consisting of the Chief Justice and such other judges as the President may from time to time .
There are many authorities who very legitimately interpret the Constitution almost daily during the discharge of their functions .
The basic function of the Courts is to adjudicate disputes between individuals between individuals and the states between the Union and the State and between the States and while so adjudicating the Courts may be required to interpret the provisions of the Constitution and the laws .
And the interpretation given by the Supreme Court becomes a law which is accepted by all the courts in the country .
There is no appeal against the judgement of the Supreme Court .
It remains the law of the land unless its interpretation is reviewed or reversed by the Supreme Court itself or the law or the Constitution is suitably amended by Parliament .
If an Act of Parliament is set aside by the Judiciary the Parliament will correct its defects by removing those which had been set aside for which it can be re - enacted .
The Parliament of India is not as supreme as the British Parliament where judicial review of legislation is not permitted .
At the same time Judiciary in India is not as supreme as in the United States of America which recognises virtually no limit on the scope of judicial review .
The Parliament of India represent all constitutionally organised shades of opinion at the national level which occupies a very important place in the political system of the country .
It embodies and प्रभुसत्ता the sovereignty of the people ; it is the voice and mirror of the nation .
Members of Parliament as elected representatives of the people ventilate the people ' s grievances and opinions on various issues scrutinise the functioning of the government on the floors of the Houses of Parliament and make laws .
The Parliament functions as the संसद and watchdog of the nation .

Parliament gets information from a variety of sources : but since the government is the largest source of information the government has to rely very heavily on government departments for its information needs .
Parliament ' s right to be informed is unlimited except that if the information given does not prejudice vital national interest or the security of the State it may be insisted upon.
As far as the activities of the government are concerned it is the duty of the Government itself to provide complete and accurate information to the Parliament from time to time .
The information is made available by ministers making statements on the floor of the House laying down reports and papers on the Table of the House or placing documents in the Parliament Library .
All the above information is important then published immediately and can be used to raise discussions in the House .
The most popular and effective medium through which members gain information is that of asking questions in the Houses of Parliament .

Parliament becomes a legitimate arena for inter - state power struggle for गतिविधि political activity or for acting out the conflicting roles and interests with parliamentary rules and procedures facilitating eventual reconciliation.
Instead of fighting to annihilate each other the parties tend to agree to disagree and to accommodate or tolerate each other .
In performing this conflict resolution role the parliamentary institution acts as a great national integrator and mediator .
In the context of our multi - pronged society the role of Parliament is especially important in टकरावों conflict resolution and unity .
In addition to the role played by the formal parliamentary forums and parliamentary procedures the Central Hall of the Parliament House is an organisation in itself .
Parliament representatives from all parts of the country irrespective of their caste creed region or religion meet informally and discuss problems which affect the country in individuals or groups .
It creates feelings of national unity which cannot be developed elsewhere .
Even those who before entering this Assembly may have some separatist regional or parochial views get cleansed and all feel themselves as citizens of a single country .
Every citizen who has attained the age of 18 years or more has the right to vote ( sex or place of religion ) .

Rajya Sabha : The members of the Rajya Sabha represent the people of the States and Union Territories .
They are elected through indirect election system and in accordance with the system of proportional representation by single transferable votes.
When the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and the Speaker of the Lok Sabha agree on the motion the Secretaries - General of the two Houses obtain orders of the President to summon the Houses on the date and time specified .

The session of Parliament usually consists of three session each year i. e. the Budget Session ( February - May ) the Budget Session ( July - September and winter months ) .

President 's Address After the newly elected members have taken oath or affirmation and the Speaker has been elected the President addresses both Houses of Parliament assembled together in the Central Hall of the Parliament House.
The President also addresses the two Houses together at the commencement of the first session of each year .
The President arrives in the State Coach at the Parliament House where he is welcomed by the President of the Rajya Sabha the Speaker Lok Sabha the Prime Minister the Prime Minister the Minister of Parliamentary Affairs and the Secretaries - General of the two Houses .
After that he is taken in a ceremonial procession to the high - domed Central Hall of Parliament along a red - कालीन route .
After the National Anthem has been played the President reads .
The Address contains details of policies and programmes which the government thinks of starting the work in the coming year .
Being a statement of government policy it is prepared by the government .
Half an hour after the President ' s Address both the Houses meet in their respective Chambers where copies of the President ' s Address are laid on the Table of the House by the Secretary - General .
The President ' s Address is discussed in both the Houses on a Motion of Thanks proposed by a member of the House and seconded by another member .
5 Discussion on the Address is very wide and one or all aspects of administration are highlighted

Within the House and in all matters connected with the House his ultimate authority is that of him .
Independence and impartiality are the two important attributes of the office of the Speaker .
He ranks higher than all the ministers in the Cabinet except the Prime Minister .
His salary and allowances are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India - that is they do not have to be voted by Parliament .
His conduct cannot be discussed except on a substantive motion .
He does not vote in the House except in case of a motion where there are two parties .
When in such a case of equality he gives his casting vote it is always in accordance with well - established parliamentary principles and conventions .
When elected president agrees he withdraws himself from his party ' s activities .
He does not hold any party post ; he does not participate in any party meetings or activities keeps away from political controversies and party campaigns .
He performs these functions in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution and the Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in Lok Sabha .
His decision in all parliamentary matters is final .
The Speaker has residuary powers to give directions in respect of cases not specifically provided in the Rules .
In doing so he may ask a member or the government to provide such facts evidence and information as may be necessary to arrive at a decision .
The Speaker has great powers to govern the functioning of the House smoothly and systematically .
He may order a member to discontinue his speech or to withdraw words or expressions which he feels are या or या .
He can also order that nothing said by a member without his permission will be included in the proceedings and that anything found is cleared from the कार्यवाही account .
The words or parts of the speech which have been ordered are not to be recorded ; or as individuals are कार्यवाही they are कार्यवाही out of action and therefore cannot be published by newspapers .
In order to create chaos in the House the Speaker may ask a member to leave the House for a day or for any part of the day or leave the House for a member to suspend a resolution being made .
All members are required to exercise discipline and they are required to take proper care in their performance and obeying their rulings and decisions.
Whenever he speaks in the middle or rises to propose or raise questions or to place questions he makes some remarks or gives his rulings he must be heard in silence .
The Speaker also determines whether there is a prima facie case for a matter relating to a breach of privilege or contempt of the House ; or the conduct of a member being held to be referred to a Committee for investigation .
If he does not give his consent the matter is not dealt further .
The statements made by the House to try to defend the honour of individuals and to prevent any member from making such a statement - LRB - not produced by him - RRB - if the evidence produced by him or by him is based on .
The Speaker has to be sensitive to the atmosphere in the House .
He communicates the decisions of the House to the authorities concerned and requires them to comply with such decisions .
All the Parliamentary Committees of the Lok Sabha are constituted by him or by the House .
They act under his control and direction.
The Business Advisory Committee . General Purposes Committee and the Rules Committee work directly under his chairmanship .
It determines what matters are financial matters which fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Lok Sabha .
If he certifies a Bill to be a ' wealthy Bill ' his decision is final .
In case of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill whenever a joint sitting of the two Houses is held he presides over such a joint - sitting and all the Rules of Procedure in such a sitting operate under his directions and orders .
It is a breach of privilege to reflect upon his impartiality , character or behaviour .
This is necessary to safeguard and maintain the dignity of the House ; if a member of the Lok Sabha is arrested in a crime a कारावास or a jail sentence is immediately passed by the Speaker or an order of the Executive .
Such intimation is also essential in the event of the release of a member .
No person can be arrested nor can a legal process be served against him in the premises of the House without obtaining the permission of the Speaker .
The Speaker is the ex - officio President of the Indian Parliamentary Group which in India functions as the National Group of the Inter - Parliamentary Union and as the Chief Branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Union .
He often leads these delegations himself .
The Speaker is also the Chairman of the Conference of Presiding Officers of Legislative Bodies in India .
The Lok Sabha Secretariat functions under the direction and control of the Speaker .

No - confidence Motion The Council of Ministers remains in office till the latter enjoys the confidence of the Lok Sabha .
In order to ascertain this confidence a motion in the above rules is made available to the effect which is called a No - confidence motion .
There is no express provision in the Constitution regarding the individual responsibility of a minister to Parliament for anything done or not done in his department .
This responsibility is सामूहित .
Therefore a motion expressing want of confidence in the Council of Ministers as a whole is admitted and the motion expressing lack of confidence individually in a minister is not in law .
37 No - confidence motion that has no effect whatsoever is not necessary to give reasons .

Otherwise it is believed that the member did not receive the leave of the House .
A motion of no - confidence once admitted has to be taken up within ten days of the leave being granted .

( a ) Budget is presented in two parts of our Parliament : i . e . the Railway Budget is presented in respect of railway finance i . e . the general budget .
The basic idea behind presenting a separate Budget for the railways is to secure stability by providing for a definite contribution by the railways and to introduce flexibility in the administration of railway finances .
The Railway Budget is presented to the Lok Sabha by the Minister of Railways sometimes in the third week of February every year and the General Budget is presented by the Minister of Finance at 5 p. m. .
The Budget is presented with a Budget Speech which is in fact one of the most important speeches in Parliament .
This speech occurs in two parts : A B has a general economic survey of the country and Part B contains ' taxation proposals for the coming financial year .
At the end of the speech of the Finance Minister in Lok Sabha a copy of the Budget is placed on the Table of the Rajya Sabha .
Soon thereafter the minister introduces a Bill which consists of taxation proposals of the government .
( a ) Discussion on the budget is essentially a deliberative body to discuss issues .
The passage of the Budget is marked by serious and thorough discussions in both Houses of Parliament .
The discussion on the Budget starts after a few days of its presentation .
It gives members the time required to study the text of the Budget and to discuss the financial proposals among themselves .
Budget is discussed in two states i General Discussion " and thereafter in detail discussions and voting on demands for grants .
Further opportunity for consideration and passed the Appropriation Bill and the Finance Bill is available to the States during consideration and passing them .
( i ) General Discussion on the Budget starts from a general debate which takes place in both the Houses of Parliament for three or four days .
First at this stage members consider the general aspects of fiscal and economic policies of the government and do not go into details of taxation and expenditure .
Thus the general debate gives each House an opportunity to express its views .
The government also becomes aware of the procedure envisaged in the subsequent phases of a particular motion .
It may be noted that in accordance with the power conferred by the Rajya Sabha it is not concerned with the Budget beyond general discussion .
( 2 ) Discussion on demands for grants - in - aid is carried out and voting in other circumstances .
Generally separate demands are made for the grants proposed for each ministry .
These demands relate to the expenditure portion of the Budget and are in the nature of request made by the Executive to the Lok Sabha for grant of authority to spend the amount demanded .
Demands are to be moved as a , in practice but in practice they are assumed to have been moved ; and are proposed by the Chair to save the time of the House .
During the discussion on demands is lively and the policy and working of the Ministry are thoroughly scrutinised .
Time is allotted to each ministry for discussing demands .
Members may disapprove of the policy of the ministry or may suggest measures for economy in the administration or draw attention of the ministry to specific local grievances .
The members can do so by moving a subsidiary motion to the basic motion for demands for grants .
These aid proposals are called " Cut Motions in parliamentary language .
The Business Advisory Committee fixes a time limit for voting a particular demand and for all demands for grants including the Budget .
As the time limit for a demand is over . the process of winding up is applied and the demand is put to vote .
Likewise on the last day allotted for all the demands not disposed of so far as they are put to vote - whether they have been discussed or not .
This process is called गिलोटिन .
At the same time the discussion on demands for grants ceases .
संसदीय by the Standing Committees dealing with Departments revealed that the demands of all the Ministries for grant of only two or three subjects were discussed in the House every year before the गिलोटिन came into force and the demands of all the Ministries were discussed.
Seventeen Standing Committees of the Departments belonging to the Departments have been entrusted with the task of considering the grants demands of the respective ministries and departments and reporting to the House before voting on demand .
After the 1994 - 95 demands were presented to Parliament both the Houses were adjourned for a mass to be examined and discussed by the respective Standing Committees .
During the 1994 Budget Session these committees presented 48 reports on demands for grants for the year 1994 - 95 .
( c ) Appropriation Bill ) Under the Constitution no money from the Consolidated Fund of India can be withdrawn without an enactment of law by Parliament .
The Bill intended to be a legal right to the government to make use of the expenditure from the Consolidated Fund as its name is obvious .
The procedure for consideration and passing an Appropriation Bill is the same as in the case of any other Bill except that the debate is confined to such matters as cannot be discussed or discussed during the debate .
After the Bill is passed by the Lok Sabha the Speaker certify that it is a Money Bill and sent to the Rajya Sabha .
Rajya Sabha has no power to amend or reject the Bill and has to give its consent to the Bill .
Thereafter the Bill is presented to the President for his assent .
( d ) Financial proposals of the government for the coming year are included in a Bill called the Finance Bill which is ordinarily introduced in the Lok Sabha after the budget is presented every year .
Discussion on the Bill covers matters relating to general administration and local grievances before the Union Government .
While the Government ' s policy is generally enough to criticise the details of any particular estimates cannot be discussed .
In short the whole administration is revised but questions which have been discussed cannot be discussed again .
This Bill has to be moved and passed by the Parliament within 75 days after its introduction and assented to by the President .
Vote on Account In a democratic set - up the government tries to give full opportunity to Parliament to discuss the budgetary provisions and the tax motions .
The passage of the Budget carries on since its presentation and voting for demands for grants and adopting Appropriation and Finance Bills ordinarily continue after the start of the current financial year .
For so long as the demands are not met the government should have enough funds to run the administration of the country .
Therefore a special provision has been made for the Vote on Account which empowers the Lok Sabha to make a grant in advance for a part of any financial year by the completion of the Budget .
During an election year if such a expectation that the main demands and the Appropriation Bill would take more than two months to be passed by the House the Vote on account may be taken for a longer period of three or four months .
As a convention vote on account is considered a formal matter and passed by the Lok Sabha without discussion .
Vote on account is passed by the general discussion on the Budget and the discussion on demands for grants is still initiated .
In the railway budget which is passed before 31 March no on account is taken but may be required in the election year .
Additional Demand for supplementary and additional grants cannot be spent without the sanction of excess over the amounts specified by Parliament .
If the amount awarded for any specific service is found insufficient for the purposes of that year or a show on a new service which is unlikely to be envisaged in the budget of the year supplementary or additional expenses are provided to the President .
If any
All such excesses are brought to the notice of the Parliament by the Comptroller and Auditor General through his report on the Appropriation Accounts .
The excesses are then examined by the Public Accounts Committee which makes recommendations on regulating the expenditure in its report submitted to the House .
Supplementary Demands for Grants are moved and passed in the House before the financial year ends while the demands for excess grants are actually made and linked after the financial year has been spent and the financial year has been brought before them .
Legislative Procedure ( a ) As soon as a legislative proposal is set up in regard to ordinary Bills a ministry concerned sees what may be its political objectives administrative powers financial and other consequences .
If other ministries or the state governments are also involved they are consulted .
Professionals and various interest groups such as business labour agriculture and industry if considered necessary are also consulted.
The Bill is thereafter examined and finalised by the administrative Ministry in consultation with all the concerned authorities .
After this entire process the Bill is prepared to be brought before the House .
The minister concerned may be introduced in either of the two Houses of Parliament .
To permit the Bill a minister has to give seven - day notice and two copies duly विधेयक of the Bill are sent to the Secretary - General of the House in which the Bill is submitted .
After the Bill has been found complete in all respects by the Secretariat it is included in the List of Business on a date fixed by the Speaker or the Chairman as the case may be specified for this purpose .
Normally copies of the bill should be made available to members at least two days before the date on which the Bill is proposed .
( Two ) Three Reading - A Bill before forming the Act passes through various stages in the Parliament .

( A ) First Reading is a necessity for the leave of the House to introduce a Bill .

Thereafter the question is put to vote of the House .

There are two types of Parliamentary Committees in India ( i ) : i . e . Standing Committees and ii ad hoc .
The Standing Committees are those which are elected by the House every year or from time to time or nominated by the Speaker or the Chairman / Chairman as the case may be constituted and constituted by the Speaker or the latter as the Speaker follows .
Standing Committees : Standing Committees in each House ( and a few Joint Committees ) can be categorised according to their functions :
Their recommendations have always been directed by the administration to keep these policies and programmes globally regulated by economy efficient and quickly.
Reports of these Committees have earned them considerable respect from all sections of the society both official and non - official .
Each recommendation is carefully analysed and processed and the administration always endeavours to remove the faults and lapses pointed out by the Committees and to act in accordance with the recommendations made by the Committees .
The Financial Committees have developed adequate procedures to ensure that the Government is made aware of their recommendations and the reasons for non - acceptance of the recommendations which are not accepted .
The progress in the implementation of the recommendations as well as the differences between Committees and the government are not answered through the Action Taken Report " .
The elaborate and effective procedure for follow - up of the recommendations made by these Committees is essentially an Indian innovation to the parliamentary procedures prevalent elsewhere .
The three Financial Committees are elected by the House for each other .
Ministers can neither become members of these Committees nor can they be asked to appear before them for their evidence .
Their Chairmen are nominated by the Speaker .
संसदीय Enquiry Committee : In a parliamentary democracy like we have : संसदीय there is an inherent right of the people to present petitions to the Parliament with a view to providing redressal and seeking constructive suggestions on matters of public importance .
This right is exercised through the Committee of Petitions .
Each House has a Committee on Petitions .
The Committee has 15 members in Lok Sabha and 10 members in Rajya Sabha .
The function of the Committee on Petitions is to examine every petition which after presentation to the House stands referred to the Committee .
The Committee reports in the House on specific complaints made in the petitions after taking such evidence as it thinks fit .
The Committee suggests remedial measures either on the specific case under review or in a general way to prevent such cases in future .
The Committee also considers representations including letters and telegrams received from various individuals and associations which are not covered by the rules relating to petitions and gives directions for their proper settlement .
This Committee has already made important contributions in providing parliamentary support to the common man in the matter of redressal of his just complaints .
It has proved to be a real boon to those wronged and oppressed citizens for whom no remedy or relief is available elsewhere .
The Committee has 15 members in Lok Sabha and has 10 members in Rajya Sabha .
To ensure that there is an effective and continuous check on the possibility of misuse of such power by the administration each House of Parliament has its own Committee of Subordinate Legislation .
The Committee of each House consists of 15 members nominated by the Speaker / Chairman .
Normally the , Committee is reconstituted every year .
The Committee examines them whether suitable provisions have been made to place their rules or orders on the Table of the House .
If the Committee concludes that the provisions made in the legislative powers delegated legislation should be revoked or amended by any means they may report to the House before the Bill is considered .
The Committee consists of 30 members - LRB - 20 from Lok Sabha and 10 from Rajya Sabha elected by the respective Houses of Parliament from amongst their members .
The functions of the Committee are mainly to consider the report of the Commissioner of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and to report in Parliament the measures taken or required to be taken by the government .
The Committee also ensures that constitutional safeguards are put into force for these backward communities .

The first rules of conduct of the sitting of the House when the House is in session should be adopted to the House - LRB - which should be followed by a few minutes before the commencement of the meeting .

Apart from the rules and conventions which are to be followed by members of parliamentary decorum in the House there are many customs and practices which are equally important to maintain proper standard in parliamentary life and to maintain the dignity of the House and its members .

In other words it stood for a solemn commitment to religious freedom for all .
This was reinforced by the principles of equality of status and opportunity and of fraternity among all the people of India .
The vision of the founding fathers was that of a nation transcending all diversities of religion caste and creed .
They were not hostile to religion but they hoped that it would be possible to forge political unity and that religious differences would not hamper nation building .
The Constitution envisaged a new social order free from communal conflicts and based on social democracy economic and political justice .
It visualized a polity under which laws would not discriminate between citizens on grounds of religion caste .
The Constitution sought to establish a 'secular' order under which the majority of the population did not enjoy any special privileges or preferential treatment at the hands of the state and the religious rights of the minorities were protected in many ways .
It seems necessary that the term secularism be clearly defined in the Constitution itself firmer legislation passed and already existing legislation firmly implemented and a radical law be passed so that no party or individual can misuse religion for political purposes .

Equality before law and equal protection of laws Article 14 of the Constitution enunciates the fundamental right of every person not to be denied equality before law in the territory of India .
The protection provided by this article is not confined to citizens alone but extends to all individuals .
It embodies the principle contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that all are equal before law and are entitled to equal protection without discrimination .
In singular in the equality before law means the same thing as the substance of law or of law or of justice .
On the other hand in the term ' equal protection of the laws " the word विधि clearly directs the statutory law and the provision made by it directs the State to ensure that all laws which they make are equitable .
However there has been no occasion for the Supreme Court to appreciate any distinction .
In fact न्यायमूर्ति Chief Justice शास्त्री Shastri has observed that the second term is the first पद result and is far too difficult to imagine the situation in which laws are not governed by the sense of equality .
( State of West Bengal v. Anwar AH Government AIR 1952 SC 75 ) .
Laws should be made applicable to all in a uniform case .
The Supreme Court has held that the varying needs of different classes of people often require separate treatment .
By V . भारत Lal v. Union of India AIR 1951 SC 41 .
If the classification is not reasonable and does not satisfy the two conditions mentioned above the impugned legislation or executive action would plainly be arbitrary and the guarantee of equality under article 14 would be violation .
Therefore wherever the state is moved in executive action - LRB - legislative - RRB - or is committed by any authority under article 12 - RRB - निरंकुशता becomes active article 14 promptly and discharged such action (
Thus the new view enunciated by the Supreme Court has widened the scope of Article 14 ' and no distinction has now been required to be made in comparison with others .
बनाम v प्राजैक्ट and इक्विपमेंट Corporation ( 1984 ) 3 SCC 316 328 .
Prohibition of discrimination on the basis of race caste sex or place of birth where Article 14 declares the nature of equality and methods in the case of a general rule in respect of a few citizens of India .
Article 15 enjoins the state not to discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion - LRB - religion - RRB - race sex place of birth or any of these .
The use of the word is only significant.
Any distinction based on one or more grounds and on other grounds or grounds would not be affected by this article ( बंबई v. State of Bombay AIR 1953 AIR 1953 SC 440 ) and no distinctions based on residence (
Clause 2 of the article provides for special enforcement of the prohibition .
The prohibition obviously covers both the activities of the State and the general public .
( A. K. Gopalan v. State of Madras AIR 1950 SC 27 ) .
It is necessary that all restrictions imposed by law whether reasonable or not arbitrary or of satisfactory nature and the onus of proving it to the satisfaction of the court lies with the state .
The more severe the restrictions the greater the भारी responsibility to prove the reasonableness ( प्रदेश Ahmad v. State of Uttar Pradesh AIR 1954 SC आर होगा ) .
Since the Constitution does not define " reasonable restrictions it has to be decided on the basis of its own merits .
G . Rao . AIR 1952 SC 196 .
The norm is really flexible and it changes time in each case with place and conditions .
The framers of the Constitution made it clear that they had not been writing the Constitution either entirely free or completely fresh .
They had deliberately decided not to neglect the past but to lay the Constitution on the basis of the framework and experience already established .
The Constitution of India had a co - ordinated development .
Category b : Bills containing provisions involving expenditure from the Consolidated Fund ( articles 110 and 117 ) .
By defining the Special Procedure for Money Bills a Money Bill has been said in Article 110 that a Money Bill is an incidental Bill containing only these matters i. e. the custody of Consolidated Fund . of a Consolidated Fund ; and
If a question arises whether a Bill is a Money Bill the decision of the Speaker shall be final .
Every Money Bill is presented to the President for his assent he shall be given a certificate along with the signature of the Speaker of the Lok Sabha ( article 110 ) .
A Money Bill can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha and only on the recommendation of the President .
When the Lok Sabha passes it to the Rajya Sabha by passing it the Rajya Sabha may make its recommendations within a period of 14 days if any and the Lok Sabha may accept or reject all or any of the recommendations .
Thereafter it is deemed to have been passed by both the Houses with the amendments accepted by the Lok Sabha .
If the recommendation of the Rajya Sabha on the amendments is not accepted by the Lok Sabha or the Council of States is not amended within 14 days it is deemed to have been passed by both the Houses as provided by article लोक .
Since we have already stated that the legislature has the power to act against evil practices for its own contempt and since it has been laid down by article 208 ( 1 ) the Legislative Assembly has laid down the rules of its action and procedure expressly .
The Legislative Assembly is the master of its own procedure and is the sole judge of the question whether its contempt has been committed .
The Government therefore decided not to amend the Constitution .
It was of the opinion that the Legislatures and the Judiciary would develop their own conventions in the light of the opinion given by the Supreme Court and the judgement pronounced by the Allahabad High Court .
The legislative powers of the President give power to article 123 President to promulgate ordinances if the two Houses of Parliament have not been running a session and there is a dispute in the matter of emergency .
The power and influence of the ordinances issued by the President are similar to the laws made by the Parliament except that all such ordinance अध्यादेश the period of six weeks from the dissolution of the Parliament or before the House निरनुमोदन .
It is only the Rajya Sabha which can declare that it is in national interest for Parliament to legislate in respect of any matter in the State List .
If by a two - thirds majority Rajya Sabha passes a resolution to this effect the Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India ( article 249 ) .
Moreover if the Rajya Sabha has by a resolution of less than two - thirds of the members present and vote it has been declared by article भारतीय of the Union of India to make such provision in the national interests fit or subject to creation .
After a new Lok Sabha is duly elected and constituted the President invites the leader of the party or parties commanding the support of more than half of the members of the Lok Sabha to form the government .
While the Prime Minister usually is a member of the Lok Sabha ministers are drawn from both Houses of Parliament .

Parliament and State Legislatures The Constitution of India has established a federal system of governance in the country as the legislative executive and financial powers between the Union and the States.
But it is extremely doubtful if Indian polity can be described as federal or federal .
The word के was nowhere used in the text of the Constitution.
In fact the proposal to describe India as a फेडरशन was specifically turned down in the Constituent Assembly .
Article 1 of the Constitution described India as the Union of States .
There are many elements in the Constitution and a large number of its provisions which are very clearly opposed to it being a federal Constitution .
Unlike the United States of America India has one citizenship ; flag is one and the Constitution is one .
The judiciary is also integrated and is not divided between the Union and the States .
In short there can be a difference of opinion about whether the Indian political system is federal unitary or quasi - federal or that it is a polity which is unitary in spirit but federal in structure .
The Union of India has 25 states at present and seven Union Territories ( as specified in the First Schedule of the Constitution .
The Executive has the right to formulate a budget .

It has full freedom to suggest how revenue should be raised to meet its expenditure. Thus the entire initiative in all these financial matters is with the government .
No taxes can be legally levied and no expenditure incurred from the public exchequer without specific parliamentary powers by law .

The procedure for the amendment of the Constitution has certain special features which clearly mark the Parliament ' s constituent capacity from its ordinary role as a legislature .
First an amendment of the Constitution can be initiated only by introducing a Bill in either House of Parliament ( Parliament ) since the initiative for making amendments to the Constitution is exclusively reserved for Parliament .
Second by and large the provisions of the Constitution can be amended by Parliament by a special majority : i . e . ii by a majority of members of each House present and voting.
Only in the case of the constitutional provisions of a limited category ( i . e . when the List of Seventh Schedule List संसद of States in Parliament ( article 368 ) ; the amendments by a special majority to be passed by the Parliament .
Third the Constitution Amendment Bill has to give his assent to the Bill after its duly introduced before the President and after the Bill has been introduced in the case such as the President has no option to withhold leave or return to the House to reconsider the Bill .
