The All - Parties Conference organised at Bombay on 19 May 1928 appointed a committee under the chairmanship of Motilal Nehru to formulate the constitution of India .
The Report embodied not only the perspective of contemporary nationalist thought but also a framework of the draft constitution of India .
The Draft Constitution of India was based on the principle of Dominion .
It laid down certain fundamental rights and provided for a federal system in which the units were given more autonomy but residuary powers vested in the Central Government .
Almost twenty - one years later it was embodied in the Constitution of free India which was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 26 November 1949 .
The White Paper issued after the third Round Table Conference outlined the British Government ' s proposal for constitutional reforms in India .
In June 1934 the Congress Working Committee declared that the only satisfactory alternative to the White Paper was the preparation of a constitution by an elected Constituent Assembly on the basis of adult franchise .
This was the first occasion when a definite demand for the Constituent Assembly was formally put .

PART II नागरिकता 5 - 11 Citizenship constitutes the indispensable foundational principle of democratic polity .
Broadly the amended section 3 of the नागरिकता fundamental Act provided that citizenship by birth could be acquired by the same person only when either of his parents was a citizen of India at birth .
Besides जन्म this Act contains provisions for acquisition of Indian citizenship by birth , appearance राज्य registration नागरिकता or through incorporation of territory.
Likewise it provided for termination of citizenship by way of renunciation voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country or through compulsory deprivation by the Government of India on certain grounds .
The Act also made specific provisions regarding Commonwealth citizenship .
26 January 1950 : Any person born outside India will be a citizen of India subject to certain requirements : if his father was a citizen of India at the time of his birth .
It is important to remember in regard to the citizenship provisions in the Constitution and this law that the framers of the Constitution decided to provide for a single Indian citizenship with the objective of building an integrated Indian nation and a united fraternity .
All citizens irrespective of their birth in any state have the same rights and duties all over the country without distinction .
PART III - III हाथों 12 - 35 When the Constituent Assembly took over the task of framing the Constitution it was for the first time to think of making a claim .
Soon after passing through various stages in the Assembly and its Committees a comprehensive letter of Rights was ready .
Dr .
Coming soon after the Universal Declaration of Human Rights the Constitution of India consisted in keeping with the contemporary democratic and humanitarian temper and constitutional practice of other countries in the world .
It was a testimony to how eager the founding fathers were to incorporate and implement the basic principles enunciated in the Universal Declaration .
Also incorporation of our Constitution became essential in view of the special problems of minorities and the urgent need to assure them of their full protection .
The Preamble declares the values of liberty and equality as well as of human dignity .
These fundamental rights substantially cover all the traditional civil and political rights enumerated in articles 2 to 21 of the Universal Declaration .
Equality before law and equal protection of all laws ( article 14 ) protection of conviction in respect of offences ( articles 20 ) व्यक्तिगत of life and personal liberty ( article 21 ) protection of fundamental freedom ( article 22 निरोध ) .
But there are some rights which can be claimed only by citizens : e. g. religion nationality living or birth based on the basis of religion nationality living sex or birth ( article 15 ) equality of opportunity in public employment ( article 16 ) .

Article 33 - 35 empower the Parliament to appeal to the armed forces by Part III of the Constitution in respect of the safeguards .
It is true that the fundamental human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India are hedged in by many limitations and restrictions .
The fundamental rights conferred to the individual are in the form of restrictions on the actions of the state .

Restrictions to protect the interests of the Scheduled Tribes have been provided keeping in view mostly the aboriginal tribes which have their own distinct culture linguistic and customs .

By attempts to avoid possible conflict between the rights of the individual and the needs of the community where on the one hand the necessary restrictions on fundamental rights are imposed on the other the more positive Directive Principles of State Policy .
It is therefore clear that these constitutional directives are not intended to be merely moral precepts but were to be treated as positive mandates and part and parcel of the human rights provisions of the Constitution .
But उपजते does not give any legal rights out of the Directive Principles a violation of which no individual can seek a remedy nor can provide any power to the legislature .
Speaking in the Constituent Assembly Dr .
Ambedkar had categorically stated that the Directive Principles were not intended to be mere pious declarations .
The Directive Principles are an effective part of the Constitution and from this point of view the Constitution seeks to achieve the ideal of a democratic welfare State in the Preamble and to the realization of the social and economic revolution that our Founding Fathers .
The Preamble the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles together .
Both the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles are the soul of the Constitution .
It is now clear that there is no essential dichotomy between Rights and Duties or between the Fundamental Rights and the Directive Principles .
They are supplementary and supplementary to each other .

In the matter of power of Parliament the Supreme Court has also made various views ( vide A . N . N . N . भारत v. State of Madras AIR 1950 SC आर ; ) of Delhi laws ( भारत v.
It has however been held in the Gopalan case that within the specified limits of its powers the Parliament is supreme .
The functions of Parliament are by law and convention to make laws .
Under article 245 - 246 Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India within its area of competence as defined and delimited under the distribution of legislative powers between the Union and the States vide the Seventh Schedule .
Only the Parliament can make laws on the Union List .
Both the Union and the States have concurrent power to legislate in respect of entries in the concurrent sphere .
If there is a conflict between the Union and the State laws the former prevails ( article 254 ) .
Also residuary powers vest in the Parliament ( article शक्तियां ) and entry of the Union List ( 97 ) .
A number of articles empower the Parliament to make laws in various matters by following such powers as may be provided by Parliament by law ( Parliament ) otherwise ) by Parliament by law ( Parliament ) by law ) and so on .
There is then no necessity for grounds no evidence or propriety .
Parliamentary control over public finance : the power to levy or modify taxes and the voting of supplies and grants is the most important checks against the Executive assuming arbitrary powers .
By law no taxes can be legally levied and no expenditure can be incurred from the public exchequer ( articles 114 - 116 and 265 ) .
Administrative accountability is ensured through parliamentary devices like प्रशासनिक and parliamentary devices like प्रशासनिक questions discussions on various motions संसद scrutiny by संसद Committee and ministers who in fact represent Parliament and control their department on behalf of Parliament .
For further studies see Subhash C. Kashyap Our Parliament . National Book Trust New Delhi .
Judges of the Supreme Court are to be paid such salaries as may be determined by Parliament by law and until so determined salaries as laid down in the Second Schedule ( article 125 ) .
When the post of the Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is unable to perform the duties of his office the President shall appoint one of the other judges of the court and he shall perform the duties of the Chief Justice ( 1987 ) .
If at any time the quorum of judges of the Supreme Court are not available the quorum of such judges to hold the session of the Supreme Court they are empowered to be appointed as judges of a High Court as they may be considered .
He can do so only with the prior consent of the President and after consultation with the Chief Justice of the High Court concerned .
The judge so appointed has a duty to give priority to the duties of the Supreme Court .

It can also be made with the consent of the President and such persons ( articles 127 and 128 ) .
Power and Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court :
The President may seek the opinion of the Supreme Court on any question of law or fact of public importance on which he thinks it expedient to obtain such an opinion .
After such reference from the President the Supreme Court will report on it to the President after such hearing as it deems fit .
The President is free to recognise it or not .
The President may by such reference seek the Supreme Court ' s opinion in regard to any treaty agreement प्रसंविदा covenant engagement . . or other similar instrument which had been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution and may be followed by the Supreme Court .
Under article 138 the Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law .
This enlarges the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and provides it with very special jurisdiction to hear cases of most immediate nature directly and in its original jurisdiction for speedy disposal .
The due process gives great scope to the Supreme Court to protecting the rights of its citizens .
It can declare laws violative of these rights void not only on substantive grounds of being unreasonable.
It is not expected to go into the question of its reasonableness suitability or policy implications.
The Supreme Court pronounces its judgement on a specific case through a specific petition .
He gives no opinion or advice on general advice .
There should be an aggrieved person who petitions the Court to challenge the constitutionality of the statute which has adversely affected his rights .
He has to show that he has sustained or is in immediate danger of sustaining some direct injury as a result of the enforcement of the statute and that the injury complained of is worth the suit .
This decision has left free individual or citizen - centric organisations to seek judicial relief in the interest of the common people .
The effect of law declared against the Constitution would be binding on all courts within the territory of India as declared by article 141 .
Therefore if the Supreme Court declares a law as opposed to the Constitution it has a legislative competence or a violation of fundamental rights it will be binding on all courts in the territory of India .
Independence : In representative democracy administration of justice assumes special significance in view of the rights of individuals which need protection against executive or legislative interference .
An independent and supreme judiciary is an essential requisite of a federal polity wherein there is a constitutional division of powers between the federal government and governments of the constituent units and a functional division of powers between the executive the legislature and the judiciary .
Also an independent and impartial judiciary is an essential requisite for ensuring human rights and protecting democracy .
Only an independent judiciary can act effectively as the guardian of the rights of the individual and the Constitution .
The Constitution provides for a High Court for each state .
Parliament may however establish by law a common High Court for two or more States or for two or more States and for a Union Territory ( articles न्यायालय and न्यायालय ) .
A higher court issues a lower court or tribunal and is intended to prohibit him from exceeding his jurisdiction .
Besides writs the High Courts under Article 226 may also issue other directions and orders in the interests of justice to the people ( T. C. 440 v. 440 AIR 1954 SC 440 ) .
( See also under High Court ) for public interest litigation : i . e . subordinate courts Madhya Pradesh iii ii .

In the matter of such appointments the High Court will have to be consulted other than the State Public Service Commission ( article के ) .
It may therefore be said that there are several States within the Constitution of India .
Generally speaking provisions for the States follow the Union - style .
At the same time the parliamentary system of government with a constitutional head and the ministers are responsible to the people of the Legislature .
The real executive power is exercised by the minister .

In practice मंत्रिपरिषद means that only a person supported by a majority in the Legislative Assembly is to be appointed the Chief Minister and the Council holds office until he has the confidence of the Assembly ( article का ) .
He may also nominate to the Legislative Assembly a person of the Anglo - Indian community ( article सभा ) if he feels the community needs representation and is not sufficiently represented in the Assembly ( article सभा ) .
The Government of India Act of 1935 proposed that in India there should be a federal polity ; the Provinces should be a central government and the Provinces deriving their jurisdiction and powers by direct devolution from the crown .
Since a limited responsible government was established only at the provincial level the nationalists naturally asked for more powers for provincial legislatures .
When the Constituent Assembly met in 1946 and early 1947 the idea was to have a federation with a Centre having limited powers .
Before the Union Constitution Committee could transact any worthwhile business the Mountbatten Plan of 3 June 1947 was declared .
All hopes of preserving the unity of the nation vanished and the partition of the country on communal basis became a firm decision .
The Union Constitution Committee and the Provincial Constitution Committee decided at a joint meeting on 5 June that in view of the 3 June announcement the limitations imposed by the Cabinet Mission ' s plan on the nature of the Constitution were lost .
When Partition became a reality there was no need to appease the Muslim League and restrict the powers of the Union Government .
If there is an के between the laws made by Parliament under article 249 and the laws made by the State Legislatures and the laws made by the State Legislatures the laws made by Parliament will be अभिभावी and 251 Law of the State shall prevail .
According to article 252 two or more State Legislatures by passing a resolution may ask Parliament to make laws on any matter in the State List .
Such laws can be extended to other States provided the concerned State Legislatures pass resolutions to that effect .
Articles 256 to 265 seek to regulate administrative relations between the Union and the States .
It is common in federal systems that the administrative relations between the Union and the States are fraught with difficulties.
The Constitution of India seeks to achieve a smooth working relationship between the two levels .
It provides that the executive powers of the State Government are utilised in such a way as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament .
The Union Executive is also empowered to give such directions to the States which appear to the Government of India to be necessary for this purpose .
Under article 258 the President may with the consent of a State Government entrust to that Government or its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the Union extends .
Similarly under article 258 a Governor of a State may with the consent of the Government of India entrust to that Government or its officers functions in relation to any subject to which the executive power of the State is enlarged .

Also the Comptroller and Auditor - General shall not be eligible to have any other office under the Government of India or any State Government .
His salary etc will be decided by Parliament by law .
The salaries of the Comptroller and Auditor General have been equated with the salary of the judges of the Supreme Court .

The Constitution left it to Parliament to lay down the duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor - General in regard to the accounts of the Union and the States ( articles 149 and 150 ) .
Article 151 however specifically lays down that the Comptroller and Auditor - General shall submit the reports relating to the accounts of the Union to the President and the President shall cause them to be laid before both Houses of Parliament .

The Contingency Fund is placed at the disposal of Union or State Government ( President or Governor ) to enable them to make advances for meeting unforeseen expenses pending authorization by the Legislature .

Borrowing Union executive power is that Parliament can borrow from the Consolidated Fund of India within limits set by law ( article 292 ) .
A State may also similarly borrow subject to limits set by the State Legislature .
The Government of India may within its borrow powers lend to any State or give guarantees in respect of loans raised by the state .
So long as any of such loans remain outstanding the State Government may not raise any loans without the consent of the Government of India ( article उधार ) .

Most of these Court pronouncements ended validity after the 44th amendment inter alia amended articles 352 358 and 359 .

By the 1919 Act and the rules made thereunder many important changes were made in the contemporary Indian constitutional system .
The seat of the Central Legislative Council is replaced by a bicameral legislature consisting of state council ( Upper House ) and the Legislative Assembly ( Lower House ) .
There is no term on the power to amend ; there is no provision in the Constitution which cannot be amended .
The fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution ( Part III ) are subject to the Parliamentary power of the Constitution - making .
In the गोलकनाथ case the Supreme Court has reversed its earlier decisions by a majority of six and held that the fundamental powers established in the Constitution are छीन article 368 without any amendments to the Constitution ( article 13 ) .
In 1973 in the न्यायालय Bharti v. state of Kerala ( AIR 1973 SC 1973 ) the Supreme Court reviewed the decision of the गोलकनाथ case .
Ten of the 13 judges held that Art. 368 itself contained the power of the Constitutional amendment and the law of Art. 13 ( 2 ) did not absorb the constitutional amendments under Art. 368 .
Accordingly the law declared in the Golak Nath case was reversed .
Regarding the question whether the power of amendment under article 368 was arbitrary and infinite ; seven judges made a majority judgement that under the " article 368 ' had the power to amend the constitution to which it was a limitation .
But what is the basic structure ? it was not clear by the majority and remained controversial .
In the संसद case after this decision the Constitution ( Urban Amendment ) Act 1976 inserted clause 4 and 5 in Art. 368 1976 and the शक्तियों of powers to amend Parliament was reduced .

On 4th November 1948 the Draft constitution of the Constitution was presented in the Constituent Assembly and recommending for a parliamentary system Chairman 1948 of the Drafting Committee said that " The Draft Constitution " was more स्थिरता than स्थिरता .
Though some sounds were heard against the idea of a parliamentary system the draft committee resolution was a very large majority in the Hindu - Muslim Council Resolution and finally on 26 January 1950 with the coming into force of the constitution of the independent India .
The three राजनीतिक representative parliamentary and democracy are the basic features of our political system .
At the commencement of the first session after every general election to the Lok Sabha and at the commencement of the first session of each year the President addresses both Houses of Parliament assembled together and gives reasons for inviting the sitting of the Houses .
Further he may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together and seek the attendance of members for this purpose .
He has the power to send सदन or any other message in respect of a Bill pending in Parliament to either House of which a message is sent in such a way that the House may consider the subject which it wants to consider .
Some Bills may be introduced or proceeded with only after the recommendation of the President has been revised .
According to the Constitution there are certain parliamentary functions which are expected to be performed by the President .
Whenever necessary he appoints a temporary chairman of the Lok Sabha ( Pro - लोक ) Speaker and the Executive Chairman of the Rajya Sabha .
It is for him to have a joint sitting in case of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill .
Every year the budget of the government . referred to as the annual financial statement in the Constitution is laid down by the संसद and the Comptroller and Auditor - General of India the Union Public Service Commission the Special Committee for Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes .
If he feels that the Anglo - Indian community is not sufficiently represented in the Lok Sabha he may nominate not more than two members to the House .
Other ministers are appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister .
It may be added that the President has no occasion to exercise his personal desire to appoint the Prime Minister .
If however a situation arises that no party gets a clear majority in the Lok Sabha then the President may make use of his judgement to pick up a leader who in his opinion is likely to command the support of the majority in the House .
The Prime Minister usually is a member of Lok Sabha but ministers are drawn from both Houses of Parliament .
A person who is not a member of either House of Parliament has to vacate the office after six months unless in the meanwhile he may be elected to either House .
At the same time every minister holds office during the pleasure of the President and can be dismissed by him .
But since the President does so only on the advice of the Prime Minister this power actually rests with the Prime Minister .
The relationship between the Executive and the Legislature is cordial and there is no scope for any opposition or division .
The two are not visualised as competing centres for power but as inseparable partners or या in the business of man .
The Council of Ministers may in a sense be described as the grand executive committee of the Parliament charged with the responsibility of governance on behalf of the parent body .
In other words the executive is not a separate or outside body .
There is however a clear distinction between the functions of the Executive and the functions of the Parliament .
Parliament ' s function is to make laws advise criticise and ventilate public grievances .
The Executive is to govern albeit on behalf of the Parliament .
In the words of the first Secretary of Indian Parliament :
Parliament should not take any part in Government ' s responsibilities for once the Parliament has begun to do so the responsibilities of the Parliament and the Executive become vague and inadequate .
Article 13 of the Constitution clearly prohibits the making of any law by Parliament the State Legislature or by any other authority which may be inconsistent with or in derogation of any of the fundamental rights contained in Part III of the Constitution .
226 confer power on the Supreme Court and the High Courts respectively for the enforcement of these rights .
Article : is opposed to the provisions of the Constitution or हनन हनन any of the fundamental rights .
It is sometimes assumed and often said that just as it is for the Legislature to make laws and for the Executive to execute them it is for the Courts to interpret the Constitution and the laws .
This is very misleading and false .
The Union ' s territory is divided among the states .
A law made by a state may be applicable only in the territory of that state .
The Union Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of India .
Parliament also enjoys the power of extra - territorial legislation i . e . a legislation made by it would not only apply to the people and property of the Indian territory but also to Indian citizens living abroad .
States do not have the power to make such legislation .
The Constitution provides for three types of distribution of legislative power between the Union and the States .
List I or the Union List contains 97 subjects over which Parliament can make laws .
List II or the State List contains 66 entries over which State Legislatures can make laws .
List III or the Concurrent List contains 47 items on which both the Parliament and the State Legislatures can make laws .
While in their respective spheres as allotted by the Constitution the Central Parliament and the State Legislatures enjoy complete autonomy the scheme of distribution of powers emphasises the general predominance of the Parliament in the legislative field .
The treaty agreement or convention with a country or on any subject in an international conference association or other body may inter - alia determine if the subject is in the state list the power to make laws .
Though requested by Parliament it may legislate on any matter in the State List .
If two or more State Legislatures consider it desirable that any of the subjects under their exclusive jurisdiction should be regulated by parliamentary legislation and pass resolutions to that effect the Parliament can make necessary legislation .
However legislation so enacted is governed by those States which have moved for this purpose and others who would approach it in the States themselves by resolutions passed in that direction .
Some of the entries in the Union List also empower Parliament to make a declaration as may be required by the Union Parliament by a statute called ' law ' and take some regions and subjects from the region of the state .
Parliament has the power to create a new State by separating its territory from any State or by uniting two or more States .
( c ) can alter the boundaries of a state ; and ( d ) in the name of a state .
These changes are not in the way of constitutional amendments but can be made by Parliament by passing a Bill by an ordinary majority on the recommendation of the President .
Such a Bill is required to be referred to the legislatures of the States concerned for the purpose of eliciting ideas within the prescribed period .
However the Bill in this way does not lessen the power of change of Parliament as it thinks fit.

The practical fact of self - government today is that the ruling power vests in the Prime Minister in his Cabinet and not in Parliament .
The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority in Lok Sabha and also the head of the government .
He may consult two or three colleagues and take action .
It is ultimately the prime minister who is responsible to the Parliament and the nation for the policies of the government . "
Administration is run by permanent civil services .
Parliament does not interfere with day - to - day administration nor does it control the administration .
Often the Press struggles hard to unearth the administrative lapses scandals and shortcomings gives expression to public grievances and difficulties and reports on how policies are being carried out .
Most of the information about parliamentary questions ready - made motions and debates comes from the daily Press and is an important instrument on which members rely .
Simultaneously the संसद Press keeps the people informed of what is happening in Parliament .
This आदान enables the Press to maintain an important and strong link between the public and the Parliament .
Considering the space that is devoted to these matters and the volume of information that is given the Press in our country fulfils a great need felt alike by the members of Parliament and the people .
Even though so much information from a variety of sources is available to Parliament it is not enough.
The information supplied by the official government sources is efficiently collected and processed but it may sometimes consciously or unconsciously become पक्षपातपूर्ण or biased and may always be strictly complete factual and objective .
Information from other sources like the mass media political parties interest groups or लॉबी would be even less so.
The government is sensitive to the opinion of the Parliament ; in most cases they are already familiar with ; in some cases they bow down and in others they feel that they cannot alter their commitments and functions according to political thinking .
However during discussions members have full liberty to criticise and suggest how they may work in the future or how a particular measure may be carried out .
Discussions affect the minds of the people on the administrative machinery and if it is not the administration is unaware of the sentiments of the people .
The parliamentary debates remind the administration of its duties and obligations .
Parliamentary debates effect the administrative thinking and action in a variety of ways and the subtle influence which cannot be measured in terms of any visible units .
While the administrators have full freedom to implement the policies suggested by the Parliament in the best manner possible they are nevertheless haunted and guided by the various viewpoints expressed in the House .
And this can be called the Advisory Role of Parliament .
To resolve conflicts and to ensure national unity is inevitable in individual life ; conflict of ideas and interests and struggle for strength by various contending forces .
Parliamentary democracy is considered to be a more civilized system of government inasmuch as under it debate and discussion on the legislative floor take the place of a war in the युद्ध battle areas .
This happens particularly when a charge is made against a person who does not have the opportunity to come before the House and clarify his position .
Before entering into admission to the factual basis of such questions . may be referred to the concerned Ministries / Departments .
Sometimes members are also asked to post material in support of the charges levelled in the question .
Moreover the question whether the subject of a question is pending before a court of law or before any other tribunal or body constituted under law or is under consideration of a Parliamentary Committee is not permitted to enquire .
It may be noted that the question should not be related to any matter which is essentially not the government of India .
Questions that contain arguments inferences or defamatory statements or otherwise refer to the character or conduct of a person not in his official or public capacity but in his personal capacity and questions which instead of seeking information are provided .
The questions are placed between starred and अतारांकित categories according to the conditions provided in the rules .
The Mission was in India from March 1946 to May 1946.
The Mission rejected the demand for Pakistan as a separate sovereign state and rejected it because it would consist of a large number of non - Muslims in Pakistan and the vast majority of Muslims would be left out of Pakistan .
The Cabinet Mission also rejected the Congress scheme of a असंगठित federation on the ground that it had constitutional disadvantages and discrepancies .
It recommended a three - tier structure consisting of the बारत unions at the top groups in the Provinces and the provinces and the native states at the lowest .
The Cabinet Mission recommended that the Constitution should be in such a manner : a Dominion of India consisting of the British Indian States and which would deal with the following subjects : Defence and Communication with them .
The Union Executive and Legislature constituted representatives of British India and Indian states .
If a leading communal question was to be raised in the Legislature it should be settled by a majority of all the members present and voting.
All subjects and rights other than those entrusted to the Union belong to the States .

The procedure in the House on such a discussion is that after a short statement has been made by a member who has initiated the discussion more than four other members सदस्य who may ask for a specific purpose .

The purpose of asking questions by definition is to get information though in practice most of the questions are to be made known .
On one side of parliamentary questions it is possible that government officials who provide materials to their representatives for questions control grievances and problems and opinions may be thrown on the other by the government ' s activities and programmes on the other hand .
Apart from the deterrent effect of parliamentary questions on public functionaries the सरकारी know by the Executive questions how policies are being implemented and how these affect the common people .
Now a days the administrative machinery is expanded enough to enable political leaders to understand the executive and the principal administrative authorities what is happening in their departments .
From this point of view parliamentary questions are of course helpful to the Executive for they bring out the essentials of the common people .
It can be said with certainty that members have been रुचि keen interest in using the right of asking questions .
It was therefore considered that some procedure may be devised whereby members might have an opportunity of bringing urgent matters to the attention of the Government .
In the modern parliamentary procedure the idea of introducing Calling Attention Notices in the Rules of Procedure is purely an Indian gift .
Used for this
Sometimes it gives opportunity to members to criticise the government directly or indirectly and to bring out the failure or inadequate action of the government in an important matter .
A member with the prior permission of the Speaker / Chairman may draw the attention of a minister to a matter of urgent public importance and request him to make a statement on the matter .
The minister may make a short statement or ask for time to make a statement on a later date .
The members' chief source for ध्यानाकर्षण the Calling Attention Notices is the daily newspaper .
Sometimes they may be based on the personal information of a member or on the correspondence he has with his constituents.
Notices of Calling Attention have to be given by members in writing by 10. 00 .
A member cannot give two or more notices for any meeting .
Notices on the same subject may be given by more than one member ; but names of not more than five members are shown in the agenda .
The Speaker looks into the notices and selects one of them for a statement by the concerned minister at the sitting of the House on the following day .
In some cases the Speaker may select two notices for a meeting .
However if the Speaker is of the view that the matter is urgent to be made by the minister on the same day he may in his discretion allow , to go on the same day as his notices have been made .
The idea behind admitting Calling Attention Notices a day or so in advance is that it would give sufficient time to the minister concerned to gather facts about the matter raised and prepare a statement in time .
No more than two notices can be taken up at a meeting to address the ministers .
There is no debate on such a statement but each member in whose name is listed is permitted to ask a question for its explanation .
The main purpose of the Calling Attention Notices is that the minister may make an authoritative statement on a matter of urgent nature .
This process does not involve any censure against the government as there is no regular discussion and voting.
In respect of matters to be addressed by the ministers some of the ports are as follows: To cause trouble in any part of India ; inter - State relations ; police ; and serious decisions made by the Courts which affect the air mines .
While raising the matter the member is not permitted to deviate from the approved text of his statement .
The minister concerned writes to the member directly on matters raised under Rule 377 informing him of the government ' s views and the action taken in the matter .
It may be noted that matters so raised are not included in the List of Business .
Prior to the fourth Lok Sabha use of Rule 377 for raising matters in the House was somewhat restricted but wider liberal attitude has since been adopted to enable Members to raise various matters of public importance particularly in their election areas .
It is seen that members are increasingly taking recourse to this rule and this process has become very popular .
While during the stay of the Fourth Lok Sabha only 36 matters were allowed to be raised under Rule 377 during the Fifth लोक sixth लोक and Seventh Lok Sabhas such matters numbered बढऋकर लोक लोक and लोक respectively.

Subsidiary motion : The motions of this class depend on other motions or relate to other motions or follow up on some action in the House .
They have no importance in themselves and are not capable of stating the decision of the House without reference to the original motion or proceedings of the House .
हैं Motions are moved in the course of debate on another question and seek to substitute that question though they are independent .

( c ) Statutory हैं These resolutions may be moved by a minister and even by a non - official member .
They are so called because they are always brought into pursuance of a provision in the Constitution or an Act of Parliament and certain Acts expressly require the government to move a resolution within a specified period of time .
If in that particular article of the Constitution or under the section of the statute to which a statutory resolution is introduced the period of its resolution is not prescribed the prescribed period of time limit for a statutory resolution is made .
A copy of each such resolution is forwarded to the minister concerned by the Secretary - General after the Private Resolution or by the House of Statutory Resolution .
In such a मनस्थिति if six months pass by the date of the Bill it is assumed that a deadlock has arisen .
Joint - sitting of the Houses : A Bill because of disagreement between the two Houses on a Bill creates an extraordinary situation in the case of a deadlock which is resolved by both the Houses at a sitting .
Under the Constitution the President has the power to summon the Bill if the Bill has not lapsed due to the dissolution of the Lok Sabha सदनों both the Houses for the purpose of deliberation and vote .
Such a joint - sitting is presided over by the Speaker and the Secretary - General - LRB - Lok Sabha - RRB - is assisted by the Speaker .
At the Joint meeting the Rules of Procedure of Lok Sabha are implemented .
Only amendments can be proposed at the joint sitting which have become necessary due to delay in passing the Bill .
The decisions at such sittings are taken by the majority of the total number of members of both the Houses present and voting.
So far only two bills the Dowry Prohibition Bill 1961 and the Banking Service Commission ( Repeal ) have been passed at joint - sitting by दहेज 1978 .
( 5 ) When a Bill is passed by both the Houses either singly or in a joint - sitting the Bill is presented to the President for his assent .
If the President . his assent the Bill ends .
The Rajya Sabha cannot reject a Money Bill nor can it amend it by virtue of its own power .
If any recommendation made by the Rajya Sabha accepts Lok Sabha the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses with the recommendations accepted by the Rajya Sabha and accepted by the Lok Sabha .
If no recommendation made by the Rajya Sabha accepts Lok Sabha the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both the Houses as passed by the Lok Sabha before the amendments recommended by the Rajya Sabha .
In addition if any passed and a Money Bill passed to him for the recommendation of the Rajya Sabha is not deemed to have been passed by both the Houses after 14 days have elapsed .
There is no question of disagreement between the two Houses on the Money Bill as in the case of a general Bill : since in the case of a simple Bill he has the same power to the Lok Sabha .
Therefore there is no provision for a joint sitting in the case of a Money Bill .
financial
Generally speaking a Financial Bill is a Bill which relates to revenue or expenditure .
However being not a Money Bill the Rajya Sabha is empowered to reject or amend it as it does in the case of a simple Bill .
Also there can be no amendment in either House without the recommendation of the President ; both the Houses except for a reduction in taxes and production of taxes and any amendment is made between the two Houses except for a simple bill and a simple one .
The provision of a joint sitting does not apply to the case of a Money Bill .
A Union Finance Bill which inter alia contains one or more proposals for expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India and which does not contain a matter mentioned in Article 110 may be submitted to the Rajya Sabha and for this reason a simple legislation .
It does not require the recommendation of the President to move it .
However the recommendation of the President is essential for its consideration by either House .
In other words it is not a condition that the President may recommend it before he does it as in the case of a Money Bill and a Legislative Body but in this case unless a Bill is passed by the President .
In all other respects the procedure of a Bill including the provision of a joint sitting in case of disagreement between the two Houses is the same as for a simple Bill .
The procedure for amendment of the Constitution ( Amendment ) was laid down in Art. 368 .
No separate constituent body is provided in the Constitution the power to amend the constitution is vested in Parliament .
A Bill to amend the Constitution may be introduced in either House of Parliament .
Such a Bill may be introduced by the government or by a private member .
Generally Constitution ( Amendment ) Bills brought forward by ministers are introduced in Lok Sabha .
Apart from being subject to the ordinary rules applicable to Bills of a non - official member it is also necessary to examine and recommend the Committee for introduction of a Bill in the House on its own behalf .
But it is not bound to accept the ideas thus gained .
By convention a motion for leave to introduce a Bill of non - official member is not opposed .
If the motion for introduction is opposed on the ground that it is outside the legislative competence of the House the Chair may permit full discussion thereon and thereafter put the motion for the decision of the House.
Normally a member can move four bills at a session .
After a Bill is introduced in the Lok Sabha and before its commencement in the House it is categorised into two categories namely i . e . ii .
In Lok Sabha the relative precedence of Bills in a particular category is determined by लोक .
The Bills are included in the List of Business.
In a parliamentary system the Legislature has to lay down the policies of the government ; law - making function and oversee the administration to be monitored .
But the enormous range and complexity of legislation and administrative functions of the modern State make it impossible for the Legislature to adequately scrutinise legislative proposals and oversee administrative action .
While the government has vast and sophisticated administrative machinery and organisation manned by experts specialists and seasoned civil servants at its' disposal to undertake its complex tasks the Legislature finds itself severely handicapped .
Through parliamentary devices like questions and debates it can keep a watch over the administration in place .
In order to make parliamentary surveillance more effective and meaningful the Parliament needs an agency which would have the confidence of the whole House .
This among other things the Parliament seeks to achieve through its Committees composed of some of its own members particularly in India .
The review of administrative action and the examination of numerous and complicated legislative proposals and subordinate legislation require expertise and close scrutiny that are not possible in the Lok Sabha consisting of 545 members .

Position of the Estimates Committee other two .

The Estimates Committee deals with estimates of public expenditure ; and Public Accounts Committee essentially examine the accounts provided by the House for the expense of the Government of India with what it is intended to ensure that money is allocated by the Parliament .
If an extra expenditure has been incurred by the House for the purpose of any service during a financial year the Committee examines the conditions for which such additional expenses have been incurred and makes recommendations .
Such excesses are required to be brought up before the House by the government for consideration of such additional expenses .
It may also record its opinion in the form of disapproval or pass निरनुमोदन against the extravagance or lack of proper control by the ministry or department concerned .
The Committee draws its subjects for examination from the audit reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India relating to the accounts of the Union which are placed before each House of Parliament .
The Comptroller and Auditor - General of India who participates in its meetings helps the भारत Committee .
The Committee has two broad limitations : one that it is not concerned with the question of policy and the other that its findings are निष्कर्ष .
In other words the Committee can point out irregularities only after they have taken place and the damage has been reached .
However the investigation is taken very seriously by the Enquiry Committee .
The very fact of the existence of such a Committee has a deterrent effect on a possible administrative waste and extravagance .

For this purpose a Committee on Public Undertakings consisting of 22 members out of whom 15 are elected by the Lok Sabha and 7 from the Rajya Sabha .

Parliamentary Museum and Archives India has always accorded maximum importance to parliamentary institutions.
से efforts have been made to harness all necessary resources for collecting and preserving the precious heritage of the country for the present and future generations .
It was initiated in 1976 when the Lok Sabha Secretariat set up a Parliamentary Archives of संसदीय and Films to preserve an extensive and up - to - date pictorial record of the history of Parliament its activities and personalities.
The proposal to set up a Parliamentary Museum and Archives was approved by the General Purposes Committee of the Lok Sabha on 1 August 1984 .
The basic purpose of the Parliamentary Museum and Archives is to enable the people to understand and realise the history of political processes and objects from the present age of the Constitution and Parliament as well as from the valuable records of the past historical documents and things .
At the current stage of its development - LRB - दस्तावेज - RRB - it is concentrating on acquisition of comprehensive documents and documentation materials available with it adequate preservation and maintenance of selected items .
In due course it proposes to undertake other tasks devoted to dissemination of information on parliamentary institutions and for creating a proper image of the Parliament by stimulating interest in its growth activities and achievements.

On the other hand the शासन or dictatorship of the individual ; and the तानाशाही government of a few people .
The fundamental signs of democracy are that sovereignty vests in the people ; the right to be fair to each individual irrespective of his caste creed colour or sex creed regardless of caste creed colour or sex creed or social background .
In a democracy people are considered their own masters .
They have an inalienable right to rule themselves or to be ruled in the way they like and by the people they choose .
Democracy also recognises the fact that from time immemorial human beings have been fighting with each other for power or for supremacy .
Democracy tries to substitute a more civilised manner of struggle .
It represents ways of संघर्ष and सशस्त्र the methods of armed conflict .
All citizens assembled together and decide the issues of governance.
It became the Commonwealth of Nations with the British Commonwealth .
The Commonwealth specifically recognised India ' s position as a sovereign independent Republic .
It did not therefore affect the sovereign democratic or republican nature of the state .
Social and economic democracy : Democracy conceived in merely political terms meant that every citizen had the right to freely vote in elections at the time .
In all democratic elections the principle of man - LRB - i - RRB - which is enforced has been derived from the recognition of the fact that all men have equal rights whether highly educated or illiterate experts .
For our founding fathers however democracy did not mean political democracy or the people ' s right to periodically vote to elect their representatives .
Without social and economic democracy political democracy had little meaning in a poor country like India .
Dr .
Ambedkar social and economic democracy was the real objective and ultimate goal .
They said that parliamentary democracy would be meaningful only if it was geared to achieving the ultimate goal of economic democracy .
Jawaharlal Nehru had later observed that Democracy of his conception was merely a means of achieving the goal .
The end is that each individual should have the best life to meet some essential economic needs .
In the measure that democracy succeeds in solving the economic problems it is also successful in the political field .
If the economic problems are not solved then the political structure tends to weaken and crack .
It has been made clear by the words of the Preamble to all citizens of the Republic securing " social justice economic and political " .
Justice means a harmony between the mutual interests of individuals between groups of individuals and groups on the one hand and interests of the community on the other .
What is more important is that the Preamble places Justice higher than the principles of liberty equality and fraternity .
The concept of justice is indeed very wide .
It is not confined to the narrow legal justice as administered by courts .
Social justice implies that all citizens are treated equally and their status in society is not taken into consideration by reason of their status in cases of justice .
Article 15 prohibits discrimination or disability in the matter of access to public places .
Provisions relating to humane conditions of work maternity relief leisure promoting economic interests among the deprived sections ; minimum wages and banning of forced labour are directed towards social justice .
Economic justice is supposed to treat the rich and the poor alike and strive to bridge the gap between them .
In pursuance of the objective of economic justice Article ; enjoins upon the state to ensure equal opportunities of employment to all citizens and women not to be exploited by adequate means of subsistence ; for the common good and by sharing of the society ;
In fact the aim of various other articles in Part IV of the Constitution ( articles 36 to 51 ) is also to ensure a new social and economic order imbued with justice .
The concept embodied in our Preamble is only that of equality of status and opportunity .
Its legal objectives are social democracy and economic aspects .
All citizens are equal in the eyes of law and enjoy equal protection of the laws of the country .
All citizens are equally entitled to enjoy political rights to vote and participate in the process of governance .
In the economic field equality means a high degree of ability and a pay for labour .
Moreover शोषण will not exploit one man or one class other people or classes .
The concept of equality of status and opportunity has been given concrete substance and shape in articles 14 to 18 .
The ideals of brotherhood justice equality freedom and equality are relevant and meaningful unless they promote the brotherhood of Indian fraternity the common Mother of India ' s brotherhood in which there are many races linguistic minorities religious and many other जातीय .
Provisions relating to common citizenship are directed towards strengthening the spirit of Indian fraternity and building a strong Indian brotherhood .
The fundamental rights guaranteed to all citizens without any discrimination and the Directive Principles directed at social and economic equality are also designed to promote fraternity .
It goes beyond separation of religion and politics freedom of religion equality of religion respect for all religions etc .
Unfortunately the concept has not been sufficiently valued by jurists and judges .
Speaking on the need for the recognition of the principle of fraternity Dr .
Ambedkar said in the Constituent Assembly : What is the meaning of fraternity ?
There is also an international aspect of fraternity which leads us to the ancient Indian ideal of universal brotherhood .
Article 51 of this Constitution clarifies under the Directive Principles .
The objective was to provide for the satisfaction of their policies by guarantees of fundamental rights of freedom equality etc and by issuing to the State in the form of Directive Principles to bring their policies in such a way that all citizens could pursue their career in good quality .
No wonder the Supreme Court found that the Preamble contained some of the basic features of the Constitution which could not be altered even by an amendment of the Constitution under article 368 .

Where an act is arbitrary it is implicit that it is unequal both in political logic and constitutional law and is therefore a breach of article 14 .

The doctrine of classification which has been developed by the courts is not article 14 ' s commentary nor is it the objective and purpose of that article.
It is only a judicial formula for determining whether the legislative or executive action of the Union is arbitrary and therefore constituting denial of equality .
The reasonableness of restrictions has to be determined not on abstract considerations but from objective manner and from the point of view of persons to whom restrictions are imposed ( हनीफ हनीफ v. State of Bihar AIR 1958 SC प्रतिबंध ) .
It is the effect of a law that really constitutes the test of its reasonableness ; its object whether good or bad is immaterial for this purpose .

Savarkar ' s trial The Hague trial was an epoch - making event in contemporary legal and political history before the Court of Arbitration vs. Great Britain before the court .
During his stay in London for five years he did not openly take action against British laws but his participation in political activities irked the British Government which was searching for grounds for action against them .
The British adopted a dubious method to suppress their voice and curb their activities .
Savarkar was proclaimed a fugitive an offender for his political activities by the Government of India and asked the British Government to remit him to India so that he could be prosecuted .
Savarkar who had gone to England as a student on a regular passport granted by him was prosecuted under the इंग्लैंड . Act 1881 .
The charges against which the British Government issued a warrant for arrest from Bow Street court London on 22nd February 1910 in an unprecedented कार्यवाही They were :
( i ) To war against His Majesty the King or to introduce war ;
ब्रिटिश
( 3 ) अस्त्र and distributing arms and हत्या the killing of Jackson ;
He was arrested in England in 1910 for the so - called speeches delivered in India in 1906 .
He was produced at the Bow Street police court on 14th March 1910 .
On April 20 the magistrate refused to release him on bail and Savarkar was transferred from Bow Street police custody to इंग्लैंड Jail in England which he was sent to India for further trial .
Mr सावरकर counsel for Savarkar made an appeal against the writ of habeas corpus and also against the decision of the Bow Street court .
The habeas corpus application and appeal were heard on 2nd and 3rd June 1910 by the Divisional Court .
The presiding judge upheld the decision of the Bow Street court and rejected the petition and the petition .
Again an appeal was filed in the High Court ; but Sri विलियम्स Williams the Chief Justice of the British High Court while upholding the judgment of the ब्रिटिश court permitted Savarkar to be referred to by the Special Tribunal to India .
Justice Coleridge who was in minority असहमति and held that Savarkar should not be sent to India but the majority view affirmed his transportation to India .
Savarkar was kept in custody till July 1910 in the British jail and preparations were made to send him to India to try his case against him .
On 26th September when the court resumed its appearance it was argued before the Tribunal that the case should be adjourned and Savarkar ' s petition against his arrest at Marseilles was sent to the French and British governments .
The objection was rejected .
On 27 and 28th September the Advocate General continued his speech .
After two prosecution witnesses had been examined the court asked Savarkar to cross - examine them if he so desired .
He added that he had left himself entirely to the French nation which was the land of liberty equality and fraternity ; so he would not take part in the trial .
Savarkar ' s counsel Mr Baptista also raised the point that सावरकर s arrest on French soil was illegal.
The court overruled all objections on 1st October 1910 .
The provisions of the प्रत्यर्पण Act were also considered .
Savarkar was asked to comment by the court and refused to say anything .
This sentence was remarkable for its political objectives in India and for its use as an example of injustice in Indian legal history .
After the trial decision Savarkar was transferred to the अंडमान Jail in Bombay ( where he was kept during trial ) to the जेल Jail and from there to जुलाई Jail where he was transferred to the Andamans on 4 July 1911 .
He was kept in a solitary कारावास but neither did he lose his self - control nor was his spirit reduced .

As in Kerala temples the temples in Kerala constituted a class by themselves which included timber in their construction to a great extent as in the south India before the advent of the stone vimana .

Most of the temples that existed at this time in Kerala are not very old ; the earliest medieval or north - medieval .
The oldest temples have been destroyed because of the perishable material ; only their stone bases and sculptures of gods dvarapalas etc . are left .
These give us an idea of the continuity from at least the tenth century AD if not earlier .
Such temples with prominent slopy or pent roofs or मानसून - roofs on मानसून are to be found extensively distributed over the entire monsoon - swept littoral from Kanyakumari in the south to south and Goa .
Their srikoyil or vimana plans include the circular विमान which is more frequent : the elliptical the elliptical the square the oblong the हैं and the apsidal ; the विमान and they are often of more than one storeyed .

The central portion of the नाली groove that rises between the front of the श्रीकोयिल gate and the outer door of the srikoyil makes usually the ardha - mandapa in the plan and therefore the main srikoyil emerges as the frontal projection of the superstructure .

Sri Aurobindo ( 1846 ) Sri Aurobindo ( Aurobindo Ghose ) was born in Calcutta on August 15 1872.
His father पिता Ghosh ( 1845 - 1893 ) belonged to a well - established Ghose family of West Bengal .
When Arvind was seven years old his father took him and his two elder brother अरविंद अरविंद and Manmohan for England .
His early education took place in an English family .
When he joined the St. Paul ' s School in London as a scholar he had already learnt Latin and read Shakespeare and the romantic poets he could .
He also learnt French and German Italian and Spanish to read Goethe Dante and दांते in the original language .
At the age of eleven he had started writing poetry in Greek Latin and English .
As secretary to the Indian Majlis Cambridge University he made revolutionary speeches hinting at armed rebellion as the only way to India ' s liberation .
Though he had passed the Indian Civil Service Examination he did not join it and returned to India in 1893 with an appointment in the Baroda State Service .
It took him thirteen years to reach the post of Acting Principal of the State College at Baroda .
He learnt Sanskrit drama Marathi and spoken Bengali and acquired a knowledge of the epics the Upanishads and Sanskrit literature; wrote poetry drama and essays in English .
He shifted to Calcutta as Principal of the newly formed National College ( now Jadavpur University ) .
Aurobindo directed the revolutionary workers to utilise the partition of Bengal for expanding their activities .
He directed बिपिनचंद्र to formulate his policy and action and organisation and introduced the famous daily " अंग्रेजी " of Bipin Chandra Pal ' s English daily " .
In the Bande Mataram का appeared a series of articles on' The Doctrine of Passive Resistance ' ' ' अहिंसात्मक out the correct method of execution of the nationalist programme of' Swadeshi ' and ' boycott ' .
In August 1907 Aurobindo was arrested for certain articles published in the Bande Mataram ' but the charge failed because it could not be proved that he was the editor of the letter .
In May 1908 along with 38 other revolutionaries he was arrested where he spent a year as " रिहाई " before release .
In jail he had the realisation of cosmic consciousness ; everywhere Sri Krishna had darshan and Sri Krishna always had the assurance of India' s freedom and of his release for the good of the world .
After his release in May 1909 Aurobindo resumed his pursuit and wrote an article on the real intention of Indian nationalism in two newly - राष्ट्रवाद कर्मयोगी कर्मयोगी ( अंग्रेजी ) and बांग्ला ( बांग्ला ) .
One evening in February 1910 he received information that his office would be searched the next day and he would be arrested .
On hearing his inner voice he left for Chandernagore and then for Pondicherry where he completely withdrew from all political activities and devoted himself to literature and philosophy .
In his mission he received the co - operation of an enlightened French फ्रांसिसी Paul Richard and his wife ( who later became the Mother of the World War ) .
In 1926 Aurobindo retired into seclusion which was till his death in 1950 .
The trial of Sri Aurobindo Ghose and others is one of the अलीपुर of historical importance which took place at a time when discontent in Bengal was at its highest level .
The trial belonged to the elite educated and enlightened people who came from the elite of society .
The involvement of the people in the trial and the like of the British High हत्याओं ' हत्याओं ' violence ' and ' ब्रिटिश ' writings ' in the evening were strengthened by this agitation .
From 1905 the political sky in the country had become छा because the disillusionment of the intellectuals in the cities were passing through the villages .
On 1st May 1908 Khudiram Bose was arrested at the खुदीराम Railway Station a few miles away from Muzaffarpur while Prafulla Chaki was arrested at the रेलवे Railway Station .
Chaki took out his revolver and shot himself dead .
A wave of shock and consternation shook India .

This historical trial lasted four - and - a - half years and involved almost the entire leadership of the communist and trade union movements across the country .

The Meerut conspiracy case exposed the true face of British imperialism against organised opposition or dissent which could challenge the political and economic superiority of the established order .
It was in fact a determined effort to crush the organised labour movement and Marxist influence in India as all the major industries and businesses were dominated by the British .
The period 1928 - 1929 was significant in Indian history for it was the beginning of an organised left - wing movement ( including all economic and political organs ) .
The organisation of trade unions enabled the workers to express their grievances and strive for better working conditions .
Although the Communist Party of India had been active for a long time in India the movement had not achieved much support by 1927 .
It was only after 1927 that during the श्रमिक श्रमिक - 29 the communists made considerable headway in their efforts to infiltrate the trade unions and the labour organisation as well as to win over a powerful section of the nationalist देशभक्त .
Even some British nationals were making their active contribution to this movement .
Soon the British Government became alarmed and undertook a series of legislative and administrative steps to nip the movement in the bud.
The most important and repressive measures were the launching of a mass conspiracy case against prominent left - wing trade leaders which greatly influenced the future of the Indian Communist Party and the whole communist movement in the country .
The Government of India was in continuous correspondence with the British Government in England and was taking instructions to adopt legislative and punitive measures .

We all know about rains which shower water .

Rain falls as pure water flows along the earth reacts with the oxides of sulphur and nitrogen to form acid .

Acid rain is thus created by industrial activities that pollute the air .
The major sources are electric power plants which are used for burning coal for power generation .
Most of the coal contain sulphur which is converted to sulphur dioxide when the coal is burned.
Why are environmental scientists so worried about acid rain ?
For it is a world - wide crisis ; the large portion of the northern hemisphere of the world it now seems to have reacted to the industrial areas of the southern hemisphere which चपेट the streams of fresh अम्लीय waters of fresh water .

What then is the simple rain - water that अम्लीय the acid waters of वर्षा and then the same धरती on the earth as acid rain ?
The change is due to the gases from industries ( oxides of sulphur ) and automobile exhausts ( oxides of nitrogen ) .
These gases react under the influence of सूर्य catalysts and sun ' s rays before dissolving in water droplets and ice crystals to form acid solutions .
These acid solutions fall to the earth as rain hail snow hail dew and mist .
A peculiarity of acid rain is that while the causative agents are emitted at one place the acid rain falls at another .
The pollutants released in one country enter the atmosphere while air currents reach thousands of kilometres and fall as acid rain in another .
For example the pollutants released in England and Germany were deposited as acid rain in Sweden and Norway .
Although Canada leaves less polluted gases in comparison to US acid rain is higher in Canada .
Rainfall knows no national boundaries and unlike other pollutants acid rain is regarded as a global phenomenon .
Since the advent of the industrial revolution in the eighteenth century man was engaged in discovering varied sources of energy for manufacturing varied types .

The problem of acid rain started in the early 1950s .

Two - thirds of acid rain is due to sulphuric acid .

The pH is an index of hydrogen ion concentration of a liquid .
अम्लीयता low pH means high concentration of hydrogen ion and high acidity .
Pure water has a pH of 7 ( पी ) which is called पी H .
The pH of water is less than 7 when it is acidic and when it is above 7 it is alkaline .
Rain water usually has a pH of less than 7 ( pH 7 ) mild acid ) due to its dissolved carbon dioxide in water - water .
The pH range of acid rain - water is 2 - 5 .
This low pH means high acidity and subsequently high अम्लीयता .
Thus water with pH 4 is more corrosive 10 times than water with pH 5 .
Water with pH 3 is still more corrosive 100 times than water with a pH 5.
If this is the case then one can imagine the corrosive nature of acid rain with a pH ranging between. 2 and 3 .

The pH is an index of hydrogen ion concentration of a liquid .
The pH of water is less than 7 when it is acidic and when it is above 7 it is alkaline .
The pH range of acid rain - water is 2 - 5 .
Thus water with pH 4 is more corrosive 10 times than water with pH 5 .
Water with pH 3 is still more corrosive 100 times than water with a pH 5.

What is Unicode ?
Unicode provides a unique number for each character है
No matter what is प्लैटफॉर्म
no matter what the program is.
Any language .
Computer कम्प्यूटर deals with numbers originally .
They store letters and characters by assigning a number for each letter and letter .
Before Unicode was invented there were hundreds of different encoding systems to provide such numbers .
No single encoding could contain enough letters : for example the European Union alone requires several different encodings to cover all its languages.
Even for a language like English the alphabet was not sufficient to provide single encoding for all the letters punctuation and technical symbols of common use .
These encoding systems also conflict with each other .
Thus two encodings can use the same number for two different letters हैं or use different numbers for the same letter .
Any computer ( especially servers ) has to support various signals for e - commerce ; yet when data is sent between two different encodings or platforms that data always has the risk of decay .
Unicode has changed all this .
Unicode (UTF - अक्षर gives a special number for each letter अक्षर no matter what the program , no matter what the language is .
The Unicode Standard has been adopted by leading players in industry such as उद्योग सन सन सन सन and सन सन .
Unicode is required by modern standards ( x M ) जावा Java स्क्रिप्ट ( Java script ) जावा L . C . पी .
It occurs in many operating systems all modern browsers and many other products .
The emergence of the Unicode Standard and the availability of its support equipment - are among the most recent global software technology trends .
By induction of Unicode into client - server or multi - dimensional devices and websites बचत large savings in spending than using traditional equipment .
Unicode provides the single software product or single website है which can be used in various देशों languages and countries without a Mumbai - based engineering .
This allows data to be transported through different systems without any restriction .
Unicode (UTF - 32 is a non - profit organisation set up to provide the Unicode Standard है which specifies the representation of text in modern software products and standards बढावा for development of के and encouraging its use .
Members of this Board include various corporations and organisations in the computer and information industry .
Membership in Unicode Consortium is open to organizations and individuals anywhere in the world who support Unicode and seek its extension and implementation .
For more information see the typical Glossary Unicode Enabled उत्पाद Unicode Enabled Products ' Technical Introduction and Useful source .

The same idea of life perpetually renewing itself of Winter throwing off its mask to reveal itself as Spring is embodied in a delightful farce which he wrote for the boys of Santiniketan ( शांतिनिकेतन ) .
The play was staged both at Santiniketan and Calcutta in which Tagore played the dual role of the poet and the blind Baul or wandering folk singers .

Having won recognition abroad Tagore had become respectable in the eyes of the British Government in India .
Gone were the days when the Government servants were warned not to send their children to their schools and they were warned .
Now the highest British dignitary in Bengal came to pay his respects.
Tagore warmly welcomed the honoured guest and made big arrangements at the asrama to welcome him .
There were even patriots who criticised Tagore for honouring the representative of the foreign ruler .
